Claim: European monarchies should be abolished.
Monarchies are costly.
Monarchy costs should be avoided, especially when people in a country are in dire need of help and taxes could be devoted to helping them.
There is no reason why millions of tax payer's money should be put into a royal family when food banks, homelessness and child poverty are on the increase in the UK.

The Queen of England spent £369 million of taxpayers money on redecorating Buckingham Palace, when that money could have been spent on improving the NHS, re-establishing community centres, providing job skill training schemes or helping the elderly and the homeless.
Monarchs are able to enjoy lavish life at the expense of taxpayers.
The Dutch royal family costs taxpayers approximately 41.4 million euros a year.
The British royal family cost the taxpayer 40.1 million pounds in the financial year 2015-2016.
When the Queen of the UK visited Australia in 2006 (a country where she is still the sovereign) it cost the Australian taxpayers $1.8 million to host her. This illustrates overall costs.
The UKs Crown Estate brought in £330 million in 2016/17, and the government kept 75%.
That is roughly comparable to the annual interest on the 9 billion pounds the UK spent to host the Olympics in 2012.
Presidents of republics and other officials also enjoy wealthy lifestyles funded by taxes.
Some of those officials are democratically elected and, when they are not, unlike monarchs, their terms are limited to a certain period and are not inheritable.

In the case of the Royal Family of the United Kingdom the evidence that they are paid for by taxation is disputed and open to interpretation depending on your source and political or ideological leaning.
In countries like Spain, where almost half of young people are unemployed, these costs should be avoided.
At the end of 2011, almost 1 in 4 of Spain's economically active citizens were out of work and the economy was in recession.
Selling off the state's possessions would create additional money in the country's budget, and reduce the tax burden for everyone in the country.
The Crown Estate, in Britain, has a capital value of £11.5 billion and the Royal Collection is valued at £10 billion.
The UK saves millions of pounds each year because the Royal Family voluntarily surrenders revenue from royal lands to Parliament.
An additional source states as of 2011 a £230.9 million income from the Crown Estate, against £32.1 million Royal Household expenditure.
The UK Crown typically brings in more money via the Crown Estates than is granted by the Sovereign Grant.
Only 15% of the Crown Estate is devoted to the monarchy.
If that land was publicly owned instead of part of the Crown Estate, those revenues would already be available to Parliament.
Seizing the land, while no doubt profitable, would be illegal.
Abolishing the monarchy would itself be illegal; the discussion already presupposes a change in the law.

Aristocrats (hereditary peers or landed gentry) still own a third of land in England and Wales. The country’s largest individual landowners are the the Duke of Buccleuch and Queensberry, the Duke of Atholls and the Prince of Wales.

The revenues from the Crown Estate given to the Government are a historical trade-off that former King George III established: in exchange for an income, the monarch offered the government the management of royal land.
Such a move would necessarily privatize what is essentially state property, erasing public property for a one-time budget boost.
Selling off everything might sound like a budget-boost. But due to free markets the actual sell value would probably be much lower, resulting in a diminishable boost on a country's budget.
Unlike any other citizen, monarchs are often exempted from paying taxes.
King Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands receives a salary that is not taxed and does not have to pay gift or inheritance taxes.
It is estimated that King Willem-Alexander will get a tax-free allowance of £4.9 million covered by taxpayers’ money in 2017.
The Dutch royal family has been obliged to pay taxes on their personal assets since 1973.
The Dutch royal family receives financial compensation for the tax they pay over their income from assets.
King Harald V of Norway does not pay any tax on his wealth.
The British Monarchy does not pay all the same taxes compared to regular citizens.
Unlike everybody else in the UK, the British monarchy is not legally bound to pay inheritance tax. It is one rule for the monarchs, and another rule for everybody else.
The rationale behind this is that the Monarch is not able to work or trade and therefore is not able to “grow” their estate in the conventional ways many of us do throughout our lifetimes
This applies only to her direct successor, gifts left to other children or relatives will be taxed in the usual way
The Queen's income from Duchy Of Lancaster is taxed.
Prince Charles pays income tax on his income from the Duchy of Cornwall.
The Queen and The Prince of Wales make voluntary payments instead of tax to compensate for their tax exemption. The are not legally obligated to do so.
The Queenhas always been subject to Value Added Tax.
Since 1993, Queen Elizabeth's personal income has been taxable as is the case for any other tax payer.
The Queen pays Council Tax
The Queen and Prince Charles pay Capital Gains Tax
In contrast, republics treat the presidents and prime ministers as regular residents for tax purposes and do not apply a highly preferential tax-free regime.
The monthly gross salary and residence allowance received by the president and the prime minister of France are subject to income tax.
In most European countries, there are no specific laws exempting Head of States from income tax. Without a specific exemption, it means that they are taxed each year the same as regular citizens.
The German and French Presidents do not enjoy any special tax benefits. (Pg.261)
Tax breaks are extremely limited in republics but not in monarchies.
The Royal Family of Belgium only pays tax on income from private sources. The civil list and the people who get allocations are exempt from tax. (Pg.256)
The King, the Queen, the Crown Prince, and the latter's wife are exempt from taxation in Norway. (Pg.247)

In the Netherlands, the three persons who currently receive an allocation are exempt from paying tax on the allocations made for them in the budget. They are also exempt from traffic and inheritance tax. (Pg.252)
The Grand Duke and his family are exempt from private income tax and the wealth tax in Luxembourg. (Pg.260)
The Queen, the Prince Consort, the Queen’s sister, Crown Prince  and the Crown Princess are exempt from personal income tax and traffic taxes in Denmark. (Pg.257)
The civil list beneficiaries of Sweden and Spain are not allowed any tax privileges. (Pg.259,245)
All members of the Spanish royal family are subject to taxation and annually submit Income Tax and Wealth Tax returns.
The Prime Minister of the UK is eligible for a 'prime ministerial expenses deduction' of £20,000 tax-free income, which no other citizen receives.
Belgium's royal family pays income and value-added tax.
The cost of monarchy is attributable to costs such as the upkeep of buildings, the number of staff, official ceremonies, travels and security details.
The buildings, staff, ceremonies, travel, and security details don't generally go away in a presidential-style democracy either.
Monarchies aren’t inherently more expensive than other forms of head of state.

The entire reign of Queen Beatrix of The Netherlands was cheaper than the money spent on the 2016 congressional and presidential election in the USA. The entire reign of Queen Beatrix was 3.762.000.000 euros ($4.429.002.600) and the US election a total of $6,444,253,265. And she brought in 148,5 billions of Euros of profit from trade.

However, it is calculated that the Dutch royal family cost its citizens €41 millions in 2017. And considering all the costs, the average cost is around 30 million euros annually. In fact, nowadays, Dutch royals are the most expensive monarchy, surpassing the UK.
The German president, which cost 25million euros in 2016, costs twice as much as the monarchies of Denmark, Sweden, Belgium, Luxembourg and Spain.
This should be looked at as a proportion of the country's tax revenue, rather than as a lump sum, as these countries vary greatly in size and economic wealth.
25 million euros is just 0.00002% of Germany's tax revenue in 2015.
Germany's tax revenue for 2015 was 9 times higher than Denmark's, 6 times higher than Belgium's and Sweden's and 56 times higher than Luxembourg's.
In 2013 the President of France cost taxpayers £91 million.
The Queen of the UK is the most expensive monarch in Europe but not the most expensive head of state. In 2013 the British Monarchy cost taxpayers £35.7 million.

That is only because the official figure for the cost of the British monarchy excludes a number of costs, including round-the-clock security, lavish royal visits and lost revenue from the Duchies of Lancaster and Cornwall. Considering all these extra costs, the British monarch is likely to be a more expensive Head of State.

Taxpayers are kept in the dark about the exact cost of the British monarchy, due to the royal household's exemption from the Freedom of Information Act and widespread misunderstanding about the nature of the royal family's finances.
In 2013 the Italian President cost the taxpayers £181.5 million.

Comparative research concludes that monarchs as heads of state are generally more costly, monarchies' budgets tend to be less transparent (and are therefore more difficult or impossible to compare) and have allocations to family members (Matthijs, p. 265).

Often members of the royal family are also entitled to an allocation or inclusion in the civil list (government payments to the head of state) in a monarchy. In republics, however, an allocation is only made to the President.
Belgium and Denmark use a very extensive system of allocations and all the children of the head of state are entitled to an allocation. (Pg. 255, 257)

In the Netherlands, the regnant monarch and the crown prince are included in the civil list. There’s also a possibility of allocations to the former monarch and their spouse (Pg.249). A similar arrangement is also practised in Norway (Pg.247) and Luxembourg (Pg.259).
A lump sum is set aside for the Royal Couple and Crown Prince and Princess in Spain and Sweden.(Pg.246, 258)
Some of the actual costs of the Spanish monarchy are included in other chapters of the state budget, making its true cost around €60 million (Matthijs, p. 247)
Republics offer greater budgetary openness as compared to monarchies.
Budgetary systems that merely specify sums of money are used in Belgium,Luxembourg, Denmark, Spain and Sweden. (Pg.255, 259, 257, 245, 258)

In Germany, the federal budget presents the costs of the President in detail and makes a distinction between the costs for the office of the President and costs related to the administration of the head of state .The Federal Audit Office is responsible for the external auditing of the budget. (Pg.261)

All expenditure related to the presidency is consolidated in a single budget in France and discussed in the standing parliamentary commission for finance. A detailed overview of all the receipts and expenses that have to do with the functioning of the head of state are given by the French state budget and the audit of the accounts of the Presidency by France’s Court of Accounts. (Pg.262)
There is a strict distinction between the public and private expenditure of the President of France and the President bears his personal expenditure himself.

The functioning of the head of state in republics is the subject of an annual report containing details about the presidential finances. There is a legal framework for this purpose in France and Germany. (Pgs. 262,261)
Royal finances are also the subject of an annual report. This is the case in Norway, the Netherlands, United Kingdom, Sweden and Denmark. (Pg. 248, 252, 253,258, 257)
The Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, Spain and Belgium do not publish annual reports related to royal finances. (Pg. 259, 245, 255)
Greater budgetary openness is no guarantee or argument for being cheaper.

The question of the state's cost in democracies is not only about the cost itself, which differs greatly among countries, but the level of transparency, which is a key element in any democratic system.
Since state budgets in democracies are funded through taxes, it is imperative that citizens can know where and how is their money spent, regardless if more or less money is actually spent.
The research doesn't take the increase in GDP through monarchy into account. One can only say that a monarchy is more expensive when the net profits are lower than a republic.

The costliness of a government is no reason for its abolition.  Governments should be maintained if they are legitimate no matter the cost (imagine  a very expensive democracy). Most monarchies are indeed legitimate because monarchs have legitimate claims to ownership of the land they control.  Hence monarchies should not be abolished.

The  Swedish monarch's accounts, which was reported at 14.5million euros in 2013, are subject to the scrutiny of the Swedish Court of Audit (Riksrevisionen) and reports are provided each year that describe their finances in great detail.
The linked research clearly shows France being double as expensive compared to the most expensive monarchy (p. 264).
It's not that monarchies are more expensive than other forms of government, but that the cost is in addition to the current government.

For instance, the Spanish monarchy costs only around €8M (€0.17/person) a year, while the Catalan public TV costs over €300M (€6.38/person). States could reduce a lot of costs before abolishing monarchies. Besides, I believe a presidential republic is more expensive.
Abolishing monarchies to save public money is useless, as some of the abolished monarchies still have a right to retain some income.
In Bavaria there is a fund that provides life stipends to former royals, besides the fact that they still retain ownership of various properties in the region (Lieb, p.28).
The Bavarian case is more an exception than the rule as most former royals (e.g. in Italy, Greece or Portugal) do not receive a stipend from their countries.
Until 2002, the Italian constitution even forbade male descendants of the House of Savoy from entering Italy.

Although Greece’s former king Constatine has been able to return to his country, he was dethroned, stripped of his citizenship and his palaces and estates were expropriated. The European Court of Human Rights ruled that the Greek state had to compensate him in damages but only for a fraction of what he asked for.
Parliament could decide to legislate to avoid making payments to former royals.
The practicalities involved in abolishing the monarchy may be more costly than the cost of keeping things as they are.
They're not causing any problems, so there's no reason to go through the hassle of restructuring them and finding a new place for their family in society.

Most European monarchies are still incredibly popular with their citizens, suggesting people do see a place for them in the 21st century. Clearly, they are not regarded as a significant democratic intrusion.
The British Monarchy has enjoyed a very high percentage of support for many decades, and republicanism seems to have never risen above 20%.
75% of the British public believes the monarch has an important role to play in the country's future.

The above linked source is possibly unreliable, since it's very pro-royal. yougov.co.uk claims that 23% of people in the UK don't believe the monarchy will be in place in 100 years' time, modest evidence that they may be seen as outdated or a thing of the past by that 23%.
70% of Dutch were happy with the monarchy in 2016 (ipsos, p. 6)
70% of Swedes support their monarchy as an institution.
82% of Norwegians are in favour of keeping the monarchy.
In a given country where the majority expresses approval for the monarchy, this institution should be maintained as that would be respecting the will of the people.

Current European monarchies have a lack of democratic legitimacy because in a majority of these countries the apparent popularity of monarchy has only ever been measured in opinion polls, never in a formal referendum or election, which is the ultimate expression of democracy.
A referendum on the popularity or future of monarchy has never been held in Britain, Denmark, Holland, Spain, Sweden or the principalities of Liechtenstein and Monaco.
Referenda can be used in a manipulative way by authoritarian or populist politicians.
High popularity ratings suggest there is not a strong need to call an official referendum on the issue.
For example, the Danish royal family is supported by approximately 71% of the population and only opposed by approximately 15%, according to a 2016 survey.
Opinion polls are consistently unreliable, and sample only a small part of the population. They cannot be considered proof of democratic consent to be subject to a monarchy.

If monarchies, in general, have not been legitimised through the urns, neither have many republics. One example is Portugal. None of the three republics that rose in the 20th century, in Portugal, were subject to referenda.
In Norway, the monarchy was endorsed and approved by a referendum. There was a landslide majority for monarchy and the royal house still enjoys a 81% approval in the people.
A referendum was held in Luxembourg in 1919 to ask voters about their preferred form of government. A large majority pronounced itself in favour of keeping the monarchy (80%).
Since 2016, the left party Déi Lénk has petitioned for a new referendum so that citizens can decide if the monarch should be kept as the Head of the State or not.
Democracy is not the only form of political legitimacy and it is fallacious to make the assumption that "the will of the people" is a meaningful or useful measure of selection of leadership.

A popular leader is not the same thing as a good leader or a useful leader; electoral history of modern democracies shows this time after time. What a person (or country) wants is not the same thing as what a person (or country) actually needs.

While democratic elected leaders in many countries may have not been the best politicians or have been corrupted or ineffective, authoritarian and totalitarian leaders, have been among the most atrocious leaders, in many cases responsible for wars and genocides.
Many authoritarian and totalitarian leaders came to power first through democratic means.
A referendum was held in Belgium in 1950 and the proposal of restoring Leopold III to the throne was approved by 57.68% of voters.

A referendum was held to give Belgians the option to decide whether King Leopold III could resume his royal powers and duties as King of the Belgians, yet they were not given the possibility to opt out of monarchy.

The principle of a republic is that the population should be allowed to decide their head of state. This right to choose cannot be denied because of with popular support right now, as future voters may not wish to have a monarch as symbolic head of state. To provide ongoing consent, each head of state should be elected.
Many television shows and comedians are also popular with every day citizens. People are interested in that which is unusual and entertaining. Not every motivation is political.
Following the scandals of the Spanish royal family, support for the monarchy in Spain has fallen.
The Spanish monarchy has been involved in a string of corruption scandals.

The fact that the Spanish monarchy has been involved in a string of corruption scandals whereas several Northern European monarchies have not suggests that monarchy is not the dependent variable in terms of varying corruption.
Cost is not the only reason for abolition.

The concept of democracy is in definite contrast to monarchy. Conceptually, while the first is a type of government that puts power in the hand of the nation’s people, the second bestows power in the hand of an individual.
Monarchs are symbols of oppression as they acquired their status by violent and immoral means, and maintained it through violence and indefensible concentration of wealth and power.
A significant portion of the Crown Estate has its origins in the Norman conquest of the British Isles. William the Conqueror claimed all land in England as his own.
When the British monarch held absolute power, he (or she) could claim any land he (or she) wanted from conquered territories. This land became the primary source of the Royal family's wealth.

As a means of preserving its control over the land and wealth of Ireland, the British monarchy allowed for the summary execution, without trial, of inhabitants. People without feudal lords were particularly susceptible to such execution.
The Netherlands, Belgium, Spain and the UK all have a colonial past that has contributed to their wealth and prosperity.
Monarchs in some democratic countries only allowed democracy when confronted with plausible threats of violence or supported undemocratic regimes.
The British aristocracy, including royals, and in particular Edward VIII, were sympathetic to the Nazi regime.
It is believed that Edward VIII colluded with the Nazis to be made a “puppet monarch” in the event of an invasion.
King Edward VIII is not representative of all kings and queens of the United Kingdom, neither he is of royal heads of state in general.
The Spanish royal family was reinstalled by a fascist dictator: Franco.
Many Spaniards still link monarchy with fascism, as General Francisco Franco had named Prince Juan Carlos de Borbón as his heir before his death.
Carol II of Romania supported the Nazi regime, passed anti-semitic legislation and evolved his government into a dictatorship.
Alfonso XIII King of Spain supported Primo de Rivera’s dictatorship and sent his son (Juan, count of Barcelona) to fight in the Spanish Civil War alongside Franco's Nationalist side.

Declassified documents and the undisclosed identity of the coup leader codenamed White Elephant, which some authors claim could have been former King Juan Carlos, suggest he was not in favour of democracy but actually supported the coup.
Republics can be authoritarian too and they can sustain regimes that are opposed to democracy. All former European communist regimes were republican.
Portugal was a republican dictatorship for nearly half a century, from 1926 up until 1974.
The Spanish monarchy initiated, approved of, and maintained the brutal Spanish Inquisition.
But those monarchs are not the same ones as the ones alive today. The ones alive today cannot be proven to approve of the Spanish Inquisition. Thus this argument cannot be used against them.
A significant portion of the wealth of the Spanish royal family has its origins in colonial exploitation of native peoples.
The monarch can be a symbol of problems, bad behavior and moral decadence.
Under King James I, Catholic worship was prohibited and Catholic priests were hunted down and executed.
An extended war known as the Reconquista propelled the collaboration between Christian kingdoms in the Iberian peninsula.
Current EU monarchies get their status from inheritance and there is not a single bit of violence involved.
However, in many cases their ancestors did resource to violence to keep power. Therefore, current monarchs are inheriting those positions through historical violence.

Every government maintains its status through violence and the concentration of wealth and power - a monopoly on violence is a defining trait of what a government is. That is therefore not enough to make monarchy particularly symbolic of oppression.
No child is responsible for the act of their parents. By the same logic the monarchs of today should not be held responsible for the actions of their ancestors.
Present monarchs may not responsible for their ancestors' acts but insofar as they still benefit from them and from a hereditary system they are to some degree complicit.
The head of state in a monarchy is a fixed, hereditary figure who takes up office by virtue of accident of birth rather than through elections and the will of the people.
The selection is unfair and inefficient.

The UK provides an example of a democracy whose continued tolerance of the monarchy opposes its other stated principles. The elimination (for the most part) of hereditary peers from the legislative branch following the 1999 House of Lords act, was based on the idea that obtaining political position through inheritance is undemocratic. This principle is incompatible with Monarchy.

It is worth noting that politically appointed life long peers in the House of Lords are not accountable to the people either and have proven to be just as open to corruption, scandals and politics of party over country, showing that even those that were put there in a democratic principle are themselves not necessarily democratic.
Kings and queens usually reign for an indeterminate amount of time and their tenure cannot be easily discussed.
Monarchy propagates the hereditary principle of power - monarchs should be selected at random from a suitable group of candidates instead.
Monarchies don't have to be hereditary, and could be elected instead. Reforming monarchies could be a better system than abolishing the monarchy.
Monarchies are not inherently incompatible with democratic principles, as elective monarchies can exist or have existed.
According to common lore, even some Americans toyed with the idea of an elective monarchy with George Washington as King following the revolution.
The founders of the United States, and George Washington himself, largely opposed the establishment of any monarchy.
An elective Monarchy has existed in Poland, where the Monarch was chosen by a body called the Sejm.
The elective monarchy used in Poland was not democratic in the modern sense. Only members of the nobility were able to vote for the king.

Because only nobles were able to vote in the election, more powerful nobles were able to exert significant control over less wealthy or powerful nobles. As a result, the elections were not very democratic even among the nobility.

Elections are not the only aspects of democracy that matter. Other fundamental characteristics, which were did not exist under the Polish elective monarchy, include the ability to freely form preferences, signify those preferences publicly, and have those preferences considered by the government on an equal basis of the opinions of others.
Even where a monarch is "elected" "democratically," by definition there is no real mechanism by which to hold the monarch democratically accountable after election.
No contemporary European monarchy is elective. All are hereditary.
They might not be chosen by a merit-based system but through the system they are nurtured the necessary skills. So the merits that would have them elected are still in the monarch.

One of the fundamental premises of democracy is meritocracy. By according royal families disproportionate wealth, influence, and power by sole virtue of their birth, monarchies undermine this principle.

Monarchies are by definition nepotistic so inherently bestow wealth, privilege, opportunities and status to individuals with no struggle/work or effort. Taking pride in monarchies is akin to taking pride in nepotism and social class snobbery.
Republics are not immune from nepotism. The USA has had political "dynasties" such as the Bushes, Clintons and Kennedys, who all practised nepotism in some format.

However, despite the power of big families, their members have had a career in politics and when given a position of power they have generally done so by being elected by the public or within a political party. Royals, on the other hand, get that power only by being born.
Monarchies have rewarded scientists, artisans, craftsmen and physicians for centuries for their skills, talents, service and their achievements for centuries.
The Royal Society was founded to reward scientists as well as encourage scientific research.
The head of the government in a constitutional monarchy, however, is a member of the parliament.
In democracies the will of the populace is the least corruptible form of decision making.
60% of the 60 most corrupt countries are autocratic regimes.
The will of the populace can be shaped by the media, which often distorts objective facts for ratings and audience.

Selective exposure theory and reinforcement theory explain how humans tend to seek and remember information that reinforces their own preexisting beliefs. Consuming more biased information just makes for even more uniformed opinions.
Social media algorithms, such as the one Facebook uses, create and reinforce echo-chambers of political views.

Studies have shown that, while people prefer to find or follow news that are similar to their own beliefs, they do not actively avoid difference. The analysis shows that Americans use the control afforded by online information sources to increase their exposure to opinions consistent with their own views, without sacrificing contact with other opinions.
Fact-checking websites and journalism awards (i.g. the Pulitzer prize) provide checks against inaccurate reporting and incentives for insightful reporting.
Lazy people, who cannot be bothered to vote in a responsible way won't bother to fact-check.
The public is often uninformed on specific policies, and votes on emotion rather than rationality.
If someone is uninformed, they are likely to vote for irrational reasons.
Ignorant or uninformed citizens are easy victims of manipulation and control.
Large parts of the British public had a misguided perception of the EU, mainly due to ignorance and misinformation, and thus voted to leave.
Interested and informed voters could have easily found out that the populists' numbers and "facts" about the EU were wrong.

People can vote in response to a hot-button issue or a scandal, or in reflection of a psychological attachment to a political party; rather than voting for the party that best represents their policy preferences.
If that issue is what they care most about at the time of the election, it is unclear why it is a bad outcome for them to voted based on it.
There is no such thing as an irrational reason to vote. If an individual chooses to vote based on how much they like the candidate's name, then that is them exercising their democratic right.
Having a right to do something does not automatically make it a good (or rational) idea to do that thing.
Uninformed decisions are not the same thing as corrupted decisions.
Uninformed decisions are still poor decisions, regardless of whether or not they are corrupted.
When people vote to have a monarchical system for their country, then that cannot be seen as opposed to democratic principles since the will of the people is taken into account.
Most of the European monarchies are constitutional monarchies, which are recognized as democracies.
Monarchies such as Norway, Sweden and Denmark are amongst the highest ranking countries on the Democracy Index.
Norway, a monarchy, is one of the most egalitarian countries in the world, according to the Gini index.

The Gini index is a measure of economic inequality. This is not relevant for the discussion of egalitarianism, which says that people should all have equal rights independent of, for example, blood line, as in the case of monarchy.

The Scandinavian monarchies (Sweden, Denmark, and Norway) are regarded as among the most egalitarian countries of the world according to the Gini Coefficient, but aside from all being constitutional monarchies, they share many other traits--there is little reason to suspect that monarchy is what sets them apart.

Gender equality, good reputation, a high quality education system (that excels in foreign languages) as well as income security and good pensions, are all factors linked to a Nordic welfare model and also the main reasons for Nordic countries' successes.
Sweden is a monarchy, yet is recognised as the most egalitarian society.

The fact that a country is a democracy does not mean there are no undemocratic power structures. In a proto-democracy all power vested in a person by the state must be either acquired through elections by the people, or indirectly through an elected official or institution that was elected by the people. If there is the potential for the monarch to override the laws made by parliament as part of that constitution, then the country is effectively not a democracy.

Even if this is the case that the functionality is somewhat different to republics, it is incorrect to define constitutional monarchies not as democracies as they are recognised as a type of democracy by states, political theorists and most civilians.

They may resemble democracies, and function as though they are democracies. However appearances are not synonymous with actualities. Unless the monarch is entirely voted for by the people, and unless the monarchy has absolutely no theoretical/hypothetical potential to overrule the democratic system, it is categorically not a democracy.
They are usually considered democracies because they have some kind of elected bodies, like parliament, government and so on. So they are considered democracies, despite the royals.

None of these European monarchies are acting as unilateral, fundamentally undemocratic powers. It is very possible for members of royalty to fully support democracy and that is the case in all of these European countries.
In a constitutional monarchy, as opposed to an absolute monarchy, power politically rests with the people, as represented by the parliament which consists of members elected by the electorate.
In a parliamentary system of democratic governance the executive branch (consisting of ministers) is held accountable to the popularly elected legislative branch (the parliament).
Unlike an elected executive, there are almost no normal mechanisms by which to hold a monarch accountable.
You can have the parliamentary democracy without the monarchy, as they do in France and many other republics. Democracy exists in spite of it, not because of it.
In the UK, the upper house known as the House of Lords is comprised of those with peerage titles. These members are not elected by the people.
The Earl Marshal, responsible for ceremonial functions, and the Lord Great Chamberlain, who serves as the monarch representative, are still entitled to a sit in the House of Lords.

It was not until 1958 that laws in the UK allowed non-hereditary life peers to sit in the House of Lords, also granting women access for the first time. Today, still 92 hereditary peers sit on the House, they are elected by the other hereditary peers by ballot and replaced on death. Very few are female and some titles can only be inherited by men.
Non-royal hereditary peerages are practically not given anymore and only four have been created since 1964 and two of those are now extinct.

Monarchies are at odds with democracy, despite the fact that many monarchies today have democratic elements. In most western monarchies, monarchs allowed democratic elements only because they were forced to.
The Magna Carta, under which the King of England recognized certain rights of his subjects, came into effect as the result of a rebellion.
The Glorious Revolution in the United Kingdom effectively ended the possibility of an absolute monarch, even after the restoration.
The French Revolution initially forced the king to head a constitutional monarchy and recognize an elected assembly. The monarchy was only fully abolished due to his resistance to that idea.
The Polish Constitution of May 1791, which transformed the monarchy into a constitutional monarchy, was the result of extensive strife and rebellions against the king.
Democracy is a form of government that has proven to promote economic prosperity and peace. A constitutional monarchy doesn't hinder this despite not being inherently democratic.

6 of the top 10 countries listed in the Legatum Prosperity Index 2016 are European monarchies. The ranking is based on a variety of factors including wealth, economic growth, education, health, personal well-being, and quality of life.

Correlation does not imply causation. There are a lot of historical and economic reasons, apart from having a constitutional monarchy, that explain why European constitutional monarchies are much richer and healthier than other countries.
Although some European monarchies are recognized as democracies in practice, the monarch, and not the people, is technically considered the Sovereign.
This is shown in the UK, in that parliamentarians must swear an oath of allegiance to the monarch (not the people).  They are unable to take their seat without doing this.

In his book, Polyarchy: Participation and Opposition, renowned political scientist Robert Dahl explained that democracy is not a binary but rather exists as a scale. Important considerations, such as political, social, and economic egalitarianism, are all undermined by monarchy.
Rule by an individual is more efficient and effective than rule by a collective.

An individual may carefully consider and reflect and examine their conscience before making a decision. Individuals also have responsibility for their actions. Collectives don't have responsibility for their actions, and their members tend to rely on every other member to take charge of the thinking for them. Also, mobs may dare to impose tyrannies that an individual would find unconscionable.
By that logic, regimes with totalitarian leaders would always be better than parliamentary systems.

Monarchy is an example of legalized inequality that goes against the first article of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR), according to which all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights.
The Head of State in a monarchy is hereditary with the eldest male child prioritised over any female siblings.
In Spain, the throne is held by Felipe VI, instead of his older sister Elena.
The monarchy of Liechtenstein practises strict agnatic primogeniture, meaning only first-born males can be heirs to the throne.
Belgium, Denmark, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and the UK now adhere to absolute primogeniture for succession, whereby the eldest child inherits the throne regardless of gender.
The only way monarchies could be acceptable would be if they were passed by referendum instead of hereditary.
The concept of a monarchy clashes with egalitarianism.
Equality before the law is one of the pillars of democratic governance. Yet European monarchs are often 'above the law', meaning that they cannot be brought into court and punished.

In constitutional monarchies the sovereign is the historical origin of the authority which creates the courts. Thus, the courts have no power to compel the sovereign to be bound by the courts, as they were created by the sovereign for the protection of their subjects.
The sovereigns of the UK, Belgium, Spain, Denmark and Norway cannot be prosecuted in their personal capacity, nor can they be required to give evidence in court.
Queen Elizabeth was reported to West Yorkshire Police for not wearing a seat belt but was not charged. According to the law, not wearing a seat belt can result in a fine of £500.

Although not required by the Constitution, in Spain, the former King Juan Carlos and the Queen have been made "aforados", meaning they can only be tried by the Supreme Court. Past actions carried out during his time as King are still immune to judgement.

The Prime Minister, his cabinet and public prosecutors are amongst the 10,000 public figures granted this legal status from the Spanish judicial system. This is not a special privilege solely awarded to the monarchs.

However, politicians and public figures lose their condition of “aforados” once they cease their functions. That is not the case of the former King who, moreover, retains total immunity for any past actions.

According to the legal doctrines of sovereign immunity and head-of-state immunity, the sovereign, state and head of state cannot commit a legal wrong, and are immune from civil suit or criminal prosecution. They aren't limited to just constitutional monarchies.
Legal immunity is not limited to monarchs. Some countries, such as Greece, grant legal immunity to members of parliament.
The existence of a monarchy sustains the traditional class system regardless of it having little or no political power.
Monarchy encourages deference and quasi-feudal behaviour.
Subjects are supposed to bow or curtsey in the presence of royals.
In the UK, visitors and staff of Buckingham palace were, until recently, supposed to walk backwards when they exited a room in the Queen's presence.
For safety concerns and potential litigations, the practice has been generally abandoned except for the Marshal of the Diplomatic Corps and the Queen's equerry.

The UK is still divided by three legal standings: the Sovereign, peers (historical hereditary peers or newly created for members of the royal family, or life peers who are granted a sit in the House of Lords) and commoners.
Monarchy encourages the perpetuation of social ranks.
According to several studies, the UK has a patent lack of social mobility explained by “entrenched elitism".
Other top professions are also comprised by privately educated people.
In the UK, 71% of senior judges, 50% of Lords and 33% of MPs attended private schools, which educate only the 7% of the countries’ children.

The existence of (unelected) Lords in the British political system is a symptom of how undemocratic monarchy is. The fact that so many Lords attended private schools is an indication that the aristocracy and royalty are both out of touch.

Out of 36 OECD countries, the UK is the fourth most unequal country (along with Spain) before redistribution, and has the 6th highest level of inequality after redistribution, being the third more unequal country in Europe.

While inequality is high in Ireland, Greece, Portugal and Spain, the UK has similar levels of high inequality, yet its GDP is much higher (and the second best in the EU) and economic indicators such as unemployment rates or debt in relation to GDP are significantly better.

In the EU, the UK is also the most unequal country in terms of GDP per inhabitant in purchasing power, with the biggest variation between the lowest and highest regions. While the national average is a little upper 100, the highest region situates the limit above 500.
The UK's lack of social mobility stems from the country's education system .
This entrenched elitism is linked to governments' history of short-term thinking, and could arguably be redressed through economic and social policies, rather than by abolishing the monarchy.
Swedish nobility still, according to most recent research, occupies many prominent positions.
Research points that social mobility in Sweden has been downplayed and that nobility still monopolise prestige occupations (Clark in Bengtsson et al., p. 17).
In Sweden, 31 of the 50 biggest owners of arable land still belonged to the old nobility in the 21st century (Bengtsson et al., p. 17).

Although in the 19th century, nobility was polarised during the industrialisation and a new ruling class, the bourgeois, emerged, high nobles became richer and, as a comprehensive research in Sweden suggest, in Europe nobility was still the dominant class afterwards, even if its total wealth was reduced (Bengtsson et al., p. 17-19).

The argument about increased share of wealth by high nobles in Sweden is based on one country and one part of its aristocracy and doesn't specifically explain the link to political power and any impact on democracy. It is therefore not sufficient.
Royal and noble ranks are bestowed by the monarchy.
British nobility still plays a role in the UK in the 21st century.
According to a recent study, in Florence, Italy - a democracy - the richest families have been the same for six centuries. So, low social mobility doesn't seem to have a correlation with monarchy.
Italy may actually prove the link between low social mobility and monarchy since it only stopped being a monarchy in 1946.
The existence of a family or lineage that inherits power or privileges through bloodline and accident of birth is contrary to the ideals of egalitarianism.
Monarchy implies superiority of "blood", which may lead to racism, far-right extremism and eugenics.
A monarchy is hardly an example for any person who wishes to accomplish a great deal from their hard work when a family have a predicated privilege to luxury.
Monarchs work harder than most ordinary people and, unlike ordinary people, do not have the luxury of retirement or promotion to look forward to in their work.
The British royal family has about 2,000 engagements, entertains 70,000 guests, and answers 100,000 letters every year.
Prince Charles worked 189 days in 2013, while MPs in the UK work at Westminster for 148 days.

The remaining 22 weeks that MPs have are often allocated to other constituency work and party conferences. Furthermore, on average politicians work 69 hour weeks , compared to an average of 42.7 hour weeks across the UK.
The Queen of England, aged 89, attended 341 engagements in 2016 alone.
Queen Sonja of Norway worked just 63 days in 2013.

Monarchs usually have inherited personal wealth which is then used to serve the country and pay for them. If they were disestablished, the country would lose access to this wealth and would therefore not save money.
Without the benefit of the crown's estate, even more of the cost is covered by the state, as seen in Ireland.
If a country eliminated its monarchy, it could seize the assets of the monarch.
Most countries are facing much more pressing issues that need attention, meaning they cannot afford to abolish the monarchy.
The UK is currently going through a housing crisis.

Many European countries are facing a huge national debt. In the third quarter of 2018, Greece's national debt amounted to 182.2 percent of gross domestic product. Italy's was 133 percent, Portugal's was 125 percent,Belgium's was 105.4 percent, France's was 99.5 percent and Spain's was 98.3 percent of gross domestic product.
Sweden is currently facing problems with refugee integration and low wages.
Unemployment levels in the European Union are high and there is a continuing stagnation in European markets.
It is possible to address more than one matter at once.
The cost of damages and compensations sought by the monarch following the abolishment of monarchy could be exorbitant.

At present, only 15% of the Crown Estate is awarded to the British Queen but, under abolition, the royal family may demand greater compensation, as the Crown Estate technically belongs to the reigning monarch.
A democratic legislature could choose not to award full (or any) compensation.

The British Royal Family's assets were acquired through their rule justified by "divine right." Because, under modern democratic theory, their rule was illegitimate, they may not be entitled to any of those assets.
The ex-Italian royal family sought 260 million euros in compensation, as well as the return of all their jewelry and property, including the Italian's president's current residence.
When Constantine II of Greece sought £320 million in compensation for his exile, he was only awarded a small fraction of his request.
It does not matter how costly the change is if the outcome is a better democracy and leads to a better government.
Monarchies often bring in more revenue than they expend.
Monarchs can also have a positive effect on business and trade relationships.
There are also other income streams that could and should be explored. Such as endorsement, pave a way for larger corporate deals internationally, use and let royal estates and more.
Brands that have been awarded the Royal Warrant reportedly benefit from up to a 5% boost in their sales, as it is a mark that symbolises quality and bestows tradition.
Political instability can hurt economic growth.
Governments come and go but the monarchy remains constant. The continuity a sovereign brings to their country ensures stability through a single figure.

Although their power is largely symbolic, in a constitutional monarchy, should the democratically elected government falter badly, the monarchy or its designate acts as an enduring and ostensibly incorruptible backstop until a new government can be formed.

Although monarchs have the power, in practice they are not the people who intervene in the case of a failing government. In constitutional monarchies, more often that not, new elections are called in the event of a failing government whereas in republics, it is often the president that takes on the ability to dissolve a government by choosing a non-electoral replacement.

In the event of a failing government, early elections are twice as common in constitutional monarchies than in republics with elected presidents, where 49% of the time they are dealt with via cabinet reshuffling instead.
Monarchy provides opportunity for psychologically deeply positive rituals, such as coronation ceremony and national celebration thereof, which can bring social unity and cohesion.
Ceremonial processions draw large crowds of people wishing to glimpse the royals passing by and wave flags. This increases nationalistic feelings and pride in the country.
Koningsdag (Queen's/King's Day) is a national holiday in Netherlands, with large-scale celebrations such as concerts and special events in public spaces.
In England, the Trooping of the Colours parade for Elizabeth II's 91st birthday drew large crowds to see the Royal Procession.
In Denmark, crowds gathered to celebrate Queen Margrethe’s 76th birthday in 2016.
Prince Harry and Meghan Markle’s wedding caused quite a stir because of the opulent ceremony.
Royals play important roles at ceremonial events, either as embodiments of unifying values, or even constants that bring past, present and future generations together.(Elgenius, pg. 293)
At ceremonies honouring people who have fought for their countries, the monarch's tribute and greeting of the parade are symbolically charged constants years on year.  (Elgenius, pg. 293)
On National Days, it is often royal ascension that is celebrated as the symbol of the country's newfound independence.
Luxembourg's National Holiday is known as 'The Grand Duke's Official Birthday'.
The Belgian National Day is celebrated on 21 July to commemorate Leopold I's royal appointment as first King of Belgium.
Sweden's National Day is celebrated in honour of the election of King Gustav Vasa, representative of the start of modern Sweden.
Hanging used to draw large crowds. The size of a crowd has no relation to the societal value of an occasion.
Non-monarchical ceremonial processions have the same effect.

In France, Bastille Day celebrates the start of the French Republic and all things French. It draws huge crowds all over the country and ceremonial processions take place in the presence of the President, rather than a monarch.
Increased nationalist feelings are not necessarily a good thing.
National pride and unity are traits that when fostered excessively are also shared with the extreme far-right and often have harmful consequences.
Far-right parties have often supported monarchy and some monarchs have historically supported anti-democratic extremism.
The Party for Freedom, a Dutch far-right, anti-Islam and anti-EU party, that among other ideas has proposed recording the ethnicity of all Dutch citizens, supports Queen Beatrix's attributions.

As a populist party, the Party for Freedom has switched views often and advocated for the queen to be only a symbolic figure (after the Queen criticised the party). Among supporters, republicanism is higher (29%)  than among the rest of the population (15%).
Former Italian monarch supported Mussolini's fascist regime while ruling. Fascism is generally considered to be an extremist form of government that is not good for the nation's common people.
Increased nationalism can fuel an increase in populism, as recently exhibited in European and US elections.

Populism and nationalism function according to different logics; while one pits 'the people' against 'the elites', the other distinguishes between those that are in a nation against those who are not.
Populism is not necessarily a bad thing

Populism can shine a light on the weaknesses of existing political systems. It can make clear which communities feel excluded from the mainstream, and it can expose the genuine failings of the status quo.
Left-wing populists' conceptions of "the people" and "the elite" are generally linked to socioeconomic grievances.

Hugo Chavez, former president of Venezuela, was highly populist in his rhetoric. His populism was centered around socioeconomic issues. Even while governing, he positioned himself as an anti-establishment politician, channeling the country's oil revenues into social programs with the aim of distributing wealth among the Venezuelan people, relieving poverty and promoting food security.
Nationalism is a form of harmful social control, as it can shape the collective behavior of groups. We should not encourage nationalism.
Citizenship is an arbitrary social construct that we use to conveniently organise societies, not anything with inherent moral importance.
Citizenship indicates membership in a political community and participation in a national identity. These things are morally meaningful.
We share many relationships with other citizens of our country - we vote in the same elections, contribute taxes to the same government, and share a national identity. This is morally meaningful.
Nationalist feelings can create an 'us' and 'them' dynamic that leads to hostility towards groups of people with different appearances, traditions or cultures.

Nationalism is a harmful form of patriotism. While patriotism is a devotion to a particular place and a way of life one thinks best, but has no wish to impose on others, nationalism is accordingly aggressive.
Jingoism, a form of ultra nationalism, can lead to individuals thinking their country is always right and other countries are wrong which can lead to conflict and war.
Aggressive German nationalism is viewed as having been a key factor in causing both World Wars.

In World War II, the Nazis sought to create a Greater Germanic Reich, emphasizing ethnic German identity and German greatness to the exclusion of all others by exterminating Jews, Gypsies, and other peoples in the Holocaust.

Nationalism is not necessarily a bad thing, as the shared sense of norms, mores, and identity that it gives citizens not only strengthens communities but helps to prevent feelings of isolation and anomie.

The fact that nationalism can shape collective behaviour does not make it bad. Shaping collective behaviour can be very good if it makes people more cooperative and willing to help each other, as nationalism does.
Nationalism is used to promote national unity and is the foundation of modern society. Sharing values, customs and an identity with others is what enables people to exhibit social solidarity.
A nation is an abstract thing that symbolises a common language, ideals, purpose, identity and group.
All nations are made up out of many different cultures and groups of people with different ideals.
National identity is important to the lives of many people.
Nationalism makes people believe in something greater than themselves, or other groups they associate with.
Nationalism can make people think they deserve better than other people due to no other reasons than the place they were born.
There's no such a thing as a national identity. There's no trait that's common to all the citizens of a nation. The very existence of such an identity is just a myth born in propaganda.

This is debatable. A National identity can be focused on an object, a tradition, a shared common history, a common core set of values, beliefs or even just a core sense of camaraderie and belonging, thus a shared common identifier.

After the First World War, British royal ceremonies such as weddings transitioned from private events to "valuable crowd-pleasers" that, removed from "party-political affairs, allowed the monarchy to remain above Parliament disputes and provided “a focus for national unity”.
Opposed to that, presidential elections, with the usual aggressive moribund negative campaign, are often exercises in hate. Such campaigns can harm mutual cooperation and help within society.
The racial diversity at the wedding of American Meghan Markle and Prince Harry is seen by some as a positive sign in multi-ethnic Britain.

Those rituals are only positive and able to provide unity if all citizens believe in a democratic monarchy as the preferred way for their state. If not, those celebrations can be as divisive as partisan politics.
The consistency of a monarch across multiple governments and plentiful reform creates a constant positive tie to the past, without blocking progression.
This certainty is a comfort to conservatives meaning that they do not feel ostracised from the developments of national politics.

The respect that the monarch's position garnered from conservatives meant that in the UK, support shown by the monarch for movement away from colonialism gave the nationself assurance to move away from a colonial past.
Their connection to the past is not always positive. Many mistakes of the past were made because of royal decisions.
This attachment to the past can itself get in the way of progress.

Monarchies can potentially hinder the further positive development of a country if a large enough portion of the population is rather living in the glorious past of that monarchy instead of looking forward.
Constitutional monarchy is an effective system of government as it avoids the requirement of republics to appoint a President or leader on a regular cycle.

As monarchs have a far longer mandate than republic presidents or prime ministers, it is easier for monarchs to establish strong and long-lasting international relationships with other monarchs or career diplomats.

The additional presidential election decreases voter turnout by 7%, due to voter fatigue. As such, government elections become less representative in republics than those in countries with non-elected heads of state.

This is a logical fallacy. Even if the turnout of voters is decreased, the elected official is still more representative than an unelected, hereditary head of state. The latter simply cannot be representative of the nation, in a democratic way. He can only be accepted or popular, but to be representative, the question (election) would have to be asked.

Politicians can be short-sighted because a government’s term is limited. Monarchs tend to be more oriented towards the long term as compared to the Parliament since they rule for a longer period of time.

Efficiency through avoiding elections is not a good argument for monarchy. Other regimes have been "effective" and avoided the requirement of republics to elect officials, such as the Soviet Union under Stalin and Mussolini's fascist Italy. However, few would say that we should implement such systems today.

The efficient systematic use of time and money in a constitutional monarchy does not necessarily translate to an effective form of government (generally qualified according to the quality of public services, welfare and democratic freedoms), the latter of which should take priority.

Periodic and regular elections are an essential part of democracy. Elections have to take place at regular intervals to strengthen democracy and to bring about peaceful transition from one government to another.

According to Article 21 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the will of the people should be the basis of the authority of government and should be expressed in periodic and genuine elections.
The Universal Declaration of Human Rights is aspirational only and not binding on monarchies.

In the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women, a binding convention, the UK, Luxembourg and Spain made reservations to protect the institution of monarchy.
Spain made the reservation that the Convention shall not affect the constitutional provisions concerning succession to the Spanish crown.
Luxembourg made the reservation to protect hereditary transition of power.
The UK made the reservation that none of the obligations would affect succession and the enjoyment of ceremonial titles such as peerage and honorific titles.
The fact that all governance relies on a single figure makes a less stable environment. Removal of the only central figure will cause more instability than removing one of many.
At times, a radical shift in politics is required to create a more egalitarian and prosperous society.
In the United States, the Civil War, and massive social disruption following the war, was necessary to abolish slavery and attempt to create a more egalitarian society without race discrimination.
Many members of society are born into wealth they did not earn, we have to accept that all births are not equal. A true egalitarian society would be very unlikely to exist.
Political instability can adversely affect growth by lowering the rates of productivity growth.
Political instability creates uncertainty, which tends to discourage foreign investment.
Not all forms of political stability are equally development friendly; much depends on the extent to which stability translates into good governance.
Instability born out of a competitive political system, where different parties must fight to gain leadership, can lead to efficiency gains which are economically beneficial.
The British monarchy has become a global brand and has an estimated value of around$84 billion.
There is frequent commentary on the range of coloured outfits that Queen Elizabeth wears.
In a survey with high and middle-income Chinese consumers, a royal connection to the British monarchy was cited as one of the top four factors in their luxury purchasing decision.
The so-called 'Kate effect', whereby items of clothing worn by the Duchess of Cambridge sell-out, is estimated to be worth over £1 billion.
British companies such as LK Bennett, Reiss and Issa, have expanded to the US after the Duchess of Cambridge wore some of their items, thanks to the international exposure it offered them.
Critics claim that the 'Kate effect' is overstated, suggesting items worn by the princess sell out merely because they are old items.
Harry Van Dalen wrote a paper claiming the Dutch Royals caused economy to grow about 1 percent per year, adding 4 to 5 billion euros to the Dutch economy per year.
Monarchies only increase trade with other monarchies.

Royalists support the monarchy to such an extent that they take pleasure in following the lives of the royals. They are interested in royal births, the health of the royal family and the day to day lives of the royals.
This interest means that there are royal reporters whose job is to comment and speculate on the royal family in the media.
Female members of the monarchy in particular are subject to the media's commentary of their choice of outfit and appearance, meaning they are under constant pressure to look a certain way.
Monarchy is an unnecessary distraction and cost when so many people are struggling and there are important issues going unreported while the media focus on the inanities of royalty.
80% of the British public said they enjoy reading stories about the monarchy 'only a little' or 'not at all'.
Monarchies generate large amounts of tourism income.
The Royal Family of the UK brings in £500 million a year in extra tourism and sales.
The British media reported that the revenue generated by Prince William and Catherine Middleton's wedding in 2011 ranged from £1 billion to £2 billion through retail spending, tourism, and pub sales.

The public holiday on the royal wedding day caused a loss of £6 billion to the economy in terms of output and revenue losses. The gains from the royal wedding are therefore worth just a third of the losses.
It is estimated that Prince George provided a $368 million boost to the British economy in the nine weeks after his birth in 2013.

The UK’s tourism body VisitBritain states that while international tourism is Britain’s third largest service export, with inbound tourism to Britain worth £26.2 billion, only some of that figure can be attributed to attractions and events with a connection to British monarchs and heritage.
Valuation agency Brand Finance has concluded that the economic worth the British monarchy brings through tourism and sales is cancelled out by their cost.

The UK royal family's overall value, including the Crown Estate and Royal Collection, was estimated by Brand Finance to be just under £57 billion in 2015, which far outweighs the overall costs of maintaining the monarchy.
Tourists are attracted to the history of monarchy and royal palaces, regardless of the political structure of the state (i.e. republic or constitutional monarchy).
It is possible to preserve the cultural and historic value of something without continuing the institution.
The Tower of London has a preserved cultural and historic value as a museum, but nobody would seriously suggest it should still be used as a form of imprisonment.

Versailles in republican France is in the world’s top 50 tourist destinations and receives more than six million visitors a year. In contrast, Buckingham Palace in Britain receives much fewer visitors.

The amount of people who purchase tickets to visit individual royal buildings does not reflect the number of people who will visit a country for its royal buildings as a whole. For instance, 49% of overseas tourists to London visited Buckingham Palace, despite not buying a ticket to go into the palace itself.
People may be considerably more interested in visiting palaces if they could see areas currently off limits such as the Queen's living areas and private collections.
It's not the history alone that attracts tourists. The celebrity status of current monarchs attracts tourists.
People still visit Versailles even if there has not been a king of France living there for centuries. In fact, removing monarchs, all of their palaces could be opened for tourism.
Monarchy avoids the exceptionally high cost of elections to determine the symbolic head of state, in addition to electing the head of government.
All national elections represent a significant expenditure.

The French government commits to reimbursing  approximately €8 million towards campaign costs for candidates who achieve more than 5% of votes in the first round. Even those who do not achieve this are reimbursed €800,000. This is a considerable investment in campaign funding alone since eleven candidates ran in the last election.
The 2010 UK general election cost £113,255,271
The US election in 2016 cost 6.8 billion per candidate.

Austria, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Finland, Ireland, Slovakia and Slovenia all elect their head of state (President) by popular vote. This is a costly addition to the expense of electing the legislature.
Money saved by not having a good elected head of state, who can stop bad policy or choose the right people for important institutions (e.g. constitutional judges), is tiny compared to the benefits.

Many European parliamentary republics (except France, Portugal, Poland, Ukraine, and Romania, that are semi-presidential systems) have a ceremonial/non-executive Head of State distinct from the executive head of government.
Many European nations, such as Estonia, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Italy, Latvia and Malta, elect their president by parliamentary vote. This avoids the cost of an election.

It is a fallacy to imply that you need to elect a symbolic head of state if you have no monarch. Switzerland is a good example of a very stable and rich country without a monarch or president (they have a rotating system of ministers in which the current chairman also acts as the head of state).
These elections mean that the head of state represents the people, this is a benefit which may justify the cost.
The choice of who should represent the nation officially, allows an opportunity for the public to decide the image which they would like to portray internationally through their head of state.
Monarchy is an outdated concept.
In order to create a politically united Europe, it will be necessary for countries to adopt similar political systems and abolish monarchies.
Political unity is crucial for Europe to maintain peace and stability in a globalized world.
The creation of a "politically united Europe" is not universally acknowledged as a necessity. In fact, many political parties represent the idea that countries should become more independent.
The European Union has never proposed any pro-presidency or anti-monarchy rules for its member states.

All member nations of the EU must be run by Democratically elected governments with free-market economies. The existence of a few hereditary Monarchies performing ceremonial and diplomatic duties has no bearing on whether a country can apply for membership or of the EU to effectively govern itself.
So far, what unites European countries are democratic and free-market values. Therefore, as long as countries uphold those values, their preferred form of government is irrelevant.
The British Queens's sovereign role in Commonwealth realms is a remnant of the British colonial Empire that prolongs the imposition of British power on other countries.

The Queen still appoints the countries' Governor-Generals, heads of state representative of the British ruler, who are responsible for carrying out the monarch's prerogative powers in these commonwealth realms.
In 1975 the Governor-General of Australia acted on behalf of Queen Elizabeth II and dismissed everyone in the Australian government after a constitutional crisis.

In 1975, following the Governor-General's dismissal of the Prime Minister in Australia, the speaker wrote to the Queen to ask for her intervention. She replied reaffirming that the prerogative powers belonged with the Governor-General and as such she had no part in the decisions that he made.

The key is "on her behalf". The Governor-General was in touch with UK seniors, but ultimately the decision to dismiss the Australian Government was his, not the Queen's. This is functionally no different to the role of a Republic's President.

Governor-Generals are nominated by the elected Prime Minister of these countries, much like would happen in a republic, and are bound by these countries' constitution. The appointment by the queen is purely symbolic.
Governors-Generals rarely exercise real power on the instruction of the Crown.

In 1926, the Governor-General of Canada refused the request of the Prime Minister, William Lyon Mackenzie King, to dissolve the parliament and call new elections. Mackenzie appealed to the British government to overrule the Governor-General's decision but the government refused, thinking it improper for them to interfere in Canadian affairs in such a way.

In 1953, the Governor-General of Pakistan dismissed the government of Prime Minister Khawaja Nazimuddin. Nazimuddin tried to appeal to Queen Elizabeth, but the Governor-General's word stood and the Queen refused to meddle.

The Governor-General still must give royal assent to legislative bills before they come into force in Australia. While ceremonial in practice, this remains an important exercise of power and a necessary element for a functioning constitutional monarchy headed by Queen Elizabeth II in Australia.

The Governor-General retains reserve powers which are important when, for example appointing a prime minister when there is a hung parliament in Australia. This involves convincing the Governor-General that they have sufficient support to command supply bills in parliament.

Queen Elizabeth II of the UK is still the Queen of Australia and New Zealand, amongst 14 others, which means that the pledge of allegiance in these countries must still be made to a distant monarch whose so-called authority stems purely from Britain's colonial Empire.
The UK no longer holds any legislative power over any other country.
The Crown is no longer imposed, and former colonies or Commonwealth realms are free to revoke it through legislature.
18 countries are no longer Commonwealth realms.
In the 21st century, with the separation between church and state, the monarch's power emanates from national constitutions rather than divine legitimacy.
Societies today include many faiths, and many people have no religion at all.
According to polls, Christianity is the largest religion in the EU, adopted by 72% of its citizens.
In previous times monarchs derived the right to rule directly from the will of God.
Roman Catholic rulers had their legitimacy supported by the Pope.

However, no current European monarchies are linked to the Roman Catholic Church anymore. The only exception is Andorra, which is not technically a monarchy but a diarchy, and has as Head of State a member of the Roman Catholic Church, the Bishop of Urgell, along with the French Prime Minister.
Protestant rulers often headed their own state churches.
Until 2012 the constitutional head of the Church of Norway was the King of Norway.

Sweden funded the Church of Sweden, its own national church in 1477: royals and elected officials could only profess this faith. Although laws gradually allowed religious freedom, it was not until 1951 that nationals could leave the Church without having to be part of another congregation, and it was not until 2000 that the State and the Church were formally separated (Jänterä-Jareborg, p. 672).
The idea of monarchy is based on the idea of a chosen person, and the descendants of such. Since science has discovered we all have the the same origins, the claim of royal or older blood is invalid.

If the doctrine of the divine right of kings was contradictory with humanity having a common ancestor, then devout Christians living before the theory of evolution was proposed, would have an even bigger problem with it, because for them our common ancestors were Adam and Eve, a mere 6,000 years ago.
The British monarch still holds the title 'Defender of the Faith and Supreme Governor of the Church of England'.

As most EU democracies are laic (or non confessional) and have freedom of religion, the connection between the Monarch and the established Church is a ceremonial leftover with little substance: therefore citizens are free to practice any religion.
Even if we stipulate that the church should be disestablished (an idea few UK citizens would agree with), the monarch's connection to it is of no practical significance.
Monarchs have let their religious beliefs come in way of their duties in recent past.

When Luxembourg's monarch refused to sign a bill regarding euthanasia because of his Roman Catholic belief, the legislature voted to amend the constitution so that the King’s approval was no longer necessary to pass a bill into law.

In 2011, the Prince of Liechtenstein threatened to use his power of veto if a referendum held in the country on abortion resulted in its decriminalisation, as he was opposed to the idea due to his Roman Catholic beliefs. Because of the Prince's broad influence, voting in the referendum lost its power to bring about change and turnout for the vote was low. Abortion is still illegal in Liechtenstein.

When King Baudoin, former King of Belgium, refused to pass a law on abortion because of religious reasons, he was sanctioned by the government as “unable to rule”. The law was passed and he was deemed able to rule again after two days, effectively removing him from political decisions without stripping him from his royal position.
