The British monarch is patron to more than 600 bodies, 433 of which she has been at the helm of since 1952.
Prince Charles' charities lobbied government ministers and senior officials to change policies on politically sensitive topics including VAT rates and regional development spending.

In the case of the British monarchy in its current state, many countries that were former colonies of Britain enjoy increased diplomatic relations and cultural similarities that may fade without the monarchy present.
Monarchs' support of issues overlooked by the government can help these causes reach the national agenda.
Princess Diana of the UK is credited with changing the image of AIDS/HIV after being photographed with somebody suffering from the illness.
Royal patronage of an organisation can lead to a growth in public support and fund-raising.
Donors are often attracted to charities with a royal patron, as it increases their chances of meeting or being affiliated with members of the royal family.
Such a process perpetuates social inequality and elitism by rewarding the social elites with special meetings with the royal family.

The Charity Market Monitor showed that in 2009 charities relating to services and veterans saw a 6.2% growth in public fund-raised income, which correlates with the British monarchy's increased vocal support for services charities at the time.
The annual Patron's Lunch at Buckingham Palace in the UK is a chance for charities with royal patrons to invite donors to encourage further donations.
It is still very common for monarchs to meet with leaders of other nations and other monarchs, highlighting their position of influence.
Queen Elizabeth II has received many leaders during state visits since 1954. For example, she received the King and Queen of Spain in 2017 and the President of Portugal in 2016.

The Queen of England reportedly used her influence as Head of the Commonwealth to persuade Jerry Rawlings, the Ghanian president, to step down at the end of his term in accordance with Ghana's constitution.
Even if this influence is not directed to her own country, it ties with UK's colonial past and proves the monarch's power.
In the UK, the Prime Minister "has a weekly meeting with the Queen to discuss current policy issues". This provides the monarch with a large degree of unofficial influence.
This power of influence has no democratic legitimacy. It is wrong to allow a person so much influence when the people whom the decision affects gave no consent to their position.
Raw political power is not the only thing that matters in social cohesion and good governance.
Where a parliamentary democracy is in place, monarchies generally have the same constitutional prerogatives as heads of state.

Constitutional monarchy is preferable to parliamentary republic, where the president's power is also ceremonial. A monarch with purely ceremonial duties is less anonymous than a president with the same limited authority, and as such a better representative for their nation.
The elected Irish president "plays a ceremonial role in the running of the State."
The President of Estonia acts as a ceremonial Head of State with no real executive power.
The elected President of Iceland has such "limited powers" that they have no term limit.
The crucial distinction is that their power is not as easily removed by parliament where it exists.
The Italian President has the Authority to dissolve the Parliament. Their democratic legitimacy means that they cannot be denied this power as easily as monarchs are theirs.
Monarchy creates social and class divisions.
The existence of a monarchy reduces the aspiration of ordinary citizens as they can never aspire to be the head of state.

In most republics, it is impossible for ordinary citizens to become head of state. In the US, you need a huge amount of money just to be considered a viable candidate to run for office. The actual cost of campaigning and running for elections is left only in the hands of the pseudo-aristocratic elite in democratic countries.

While running for president in the US is very expensive, European elections are generally cheaper, funding is provided by the party and even funded by the government and there are limits on the amount candidates can spend.
Even in supranational entities like the European Union, political parties with representation also receive EU funding.

There's nothing stopping a citizen from aspiring to be the head of state, either by desiring to abolish monarchy and become president, or to depose the existing monarchy and crown oneself king. These are less plausible ambitions than just winning an election, but "can never aspire to" is a strong claim.
A system of royal honors and privileges keeps the traditional social structures intact which makes social and political change less possible.

Maybe in pre-revolution France where repressive social classes and religious mandates were brutally enforced by the royalty, but none of the modern European monarchies we are discussing resemble this in any way. It is unclear how a symbolic monarchy makes social structures more rigid.
A system of royal honours and privileges allow the monarch to bypass stagnant social class and recognize anyone, regardless of upbringing, as being worthy of recognition and praise.
The British honours system rewards people on the basis of their bravery, their contributions to a particular industry or their charitable services; it is a deeply meritocratic system.

Monarchs aiming to acknowledge and reward merit still perpetuate the foundation of unequal access to power and very high risk of biased application. The best vehicles for meritocracy include safeguards like transparency and democracy and scholarship.
The UK honours system is run by the Government of which the monarch is but a part. It is just as susceptible as any such system to cronyism and biased decisions about who should receive an award.
Social and political change is not intrinsically desirable.

Social classes are necessary for hierarchy to exist. Hierarchy is necessary for social stability and allows civilisation to exist and flourish. Without hierarchy, societies become less stable, less mannerly and less happy and thus deteriorate.
Social and political change is evolutionary so happens whether desired or not.
Monarchies enshrine a system of nepotism and cronyism. People close to the royals have unfair advantages over common people

Anybody close to the people in power, regardless of democracy or any form of government have advantages over common people; nepotism and cronyism can occur anywhere. All peers in the UK House of Lords are appointed solely by the democratically elected Prime Minister. The House of Lords has been full of PM's cronies for the last hundred years, and swells in size with each new appointed PM.
While monarchy leads to less representation for members of society, it is more likely to provide female heads of state than elections.

Even in situations where male siblings were given precedence, monarchy lead to female heads of state before democratic structures allowed it. The United Kingdom had its first Queen in 1553. This is to be commended when in 2016, still only "10% of 193 UN member states" have an elected, female head of state.
The number of female elected heads of states has increased steadily over time. As societies develop, more and more female heads of state will be elected.

In a republic, even if the odds are stacked against female candidates, it is possible for any woman to become head of state. In a monarchy, this privilege is unfairly restricted to women within one family.

While the proportion of elected heads of state who are female is steadily increasing, the chance that the heir to the throne will be female is decided by birth, and so will not constantly increase. This means that over time democratic elections may become more likely to select a female head of state than monarchy.

Democratic elections are proving very slow to appoint female candidates to positions of power. It was not until 1960 that the first female Prime Minister was elected, and at present, there are only 15 female democratically elected heads of state.
Even if achieving more female representation is a a good and noble goal, if those who achieve it are only from a higher-up extract in society, then this may not be more equal representation.

The world in which royalty grow up, with wealth and privilege which is unknown to the majority of the population, may be so different that a Queen is not relatable to or representative of the majority of women in society.
Monarchs, born into a life of privilege and luxury, can't relate to the lives of most of their citizens. Being so out of touch makes it harder to rule effectively.

The former king of Spain, Juan Carlos, was criticised for undertaking an expensive and elitist hunting trip during which he shot elephants in Botswana at a time when his country was struggling with unemployment and an economic crisis.
Politicians who have lived experience in areas such as law, business, economics, or public service are able to govern more effectively than a royal who has never experienced work.

The most common professions for politicians around the world are law and business, as the skills displayed in both professions, such as command of procedure and diplomacy, translate well to the political sphere.
In France, when Nicolas Sarkozy was President, 9 out of 16 in his first cabinet were lawyers or law graduates, including the president, the prime minister and the finance minister.
Donald Trump, whose experience prior to becoming the President of the US was primarily in business, is regarded as one of the worst presidents in history.

While these professions may have skills to assist them in politics, lawyers are typically regarded in polls in England as not a trusted profession. This impacts on their ability to govern effectively in the eyes of the populous.
Many monarchs and future monarchs do have jobs.
Queen Elizabeth served in the Auxiliary Territorial Service, the women's branch of the British Army during the Second World War.
The Spanish monarch was accused of being out of touch with its country's troubled economic situation after mistakenly shaking a beggar's hand.

Not all politicians are chosen considering their balanced background or education. Falling out of touch depends on the individual's character, or how he/she reacts to the privileges that come with the position of power/wealth, not to any form government.
Politicians are also accused of being out-of-touch due to their privileged backgrounds.
48% of Conservative MPs and 17% of Labour MPs in the UK attended private schools, while just 7% of the country's children do.

In 1979, only 3.4% of MPs in the UK were previously employed in politics, yet in 2010 they represent the 15% of the total. The tendency in the last years shows that the number of career politicians rises, while the number of professionals and manual labourers declines and those coming from business remain stable.
19 out of 54 of the UK's Prime Ministers attended Eton, an expensive boarding school for boys with an elitist reputation.

In this case it is not about equality across all factors, only for gender. And in most European monarchies (with the advent of absolute primogeniture) today there is a 50-50 chance of having a female head of state - while top political positions are a far cry from this level of equality.
Race and economic inequality are greater causes of social and class divide than a monarchical presence.
There is a 12% employment gap in the UK  between white British and racial minority groups.
America, which has never had a monarchy, struggles with class divide fuelled by economic gaps and racial inequality.
Racism, classism and sexism are all principles reinforced by having European monarchs which were generally rich, Caucasian males with little room for change in any of those aspects.

Monarchy is most often supra-national. Before the onset of WWI, all except two European monarchies were dual monarchies or ruled by a monarch of foreign nationality (e.g. the House of Windsor is actually German), and intermarriage with foreign monarchs in the mutual benefit of their kingdoms was encouraged.

Intermarriage across countries between royal families (all of them Caucasian and European) only strengthens the lack of diversity in terms of race, ethnicity and upbringing that are characteristic of royal families.
Regardless of whether the monarchy is supranational, European monarchs were nearly all rich, white, and men. It was structurally not possible for a non-white, non-wealthy person to become a monarch.
This does not deny the fact that a monarch is a symbol of inequality, as it perpetuates the class system and undermines the proper recognition of merit.
Monarchies exacerbate racial and economic inequality by empowering--either culturally, economically, or politically--a single race and economic class.

While it is true that class differences exist in monarchies, this is also true of systems that are the polar opposite. Even the old Soviet Union and its client states had its upper class people with private estates to which the ordinary citizens were not invited.
There is nothing inherently wrong with social and class divisions.

When the class division increases, the people born in the upper class will be more respected by the society, not because of what they have achieved but because of what the family they are born into. And the people in the lower will have less opportunities available for them to take advantage of.
Extreme example is the caste system in India. It essentially hinders the flourishing of human potential.
Monarchy is fundamentally opposed to democratic principles.
There is a lack of accountability in constitutional monarchies.
Monarchs are not elected.
Monarchs are not held accountable to people through ballot boxes once they fail to become effective leaders.

Citizens do not have the choice or freedom to withdraw support for an ineffective monarch through the ballot as in the case of a republic and have to resort to violent ways such as a coup, revolution or civil war to oppose the monarchy.

The strike against King Leopold III of Belgium is one of the most violent general strikes in the history of Belgium and Belgium stood on the brink of civil war. It could have been avoided if a less violent and easier alternative to change the monarch was available to the people.

Monarchs are beholden to the social mores of the kingdom as well as to the spiritual realm. Historically, the result of a monarch who could not abide by these rules was often regicide. Therefore if the king didn’t listen to the people and the Pope, he was as good as dead.
In the UK, Section 3 of the Treason Felony Act 1848 makes it a criminal offence, punishable by life imprisonment, to advocate abolition of the monarchy.
Section 3 of the Treason Felony Act 1848 has not been deployed in a prosecution since 1879.

The Guardian's legal challenge to the 1848 Treason Felony Act was dismissed by the House of Lords and ruled as unnecessary since the paper had published articles that espoused republican views, and had not been prosecuted.
Even so, it remains in the statute book and there remains the possibility it could be used by the state to prosecute individuals for comments advocating for the abolition of the monarch.

Statutes carry significant symbolic weight even if they are rarely used. For example, the ban on sodomy struck down in the United States Supreme Court decision in Lawrence v. Texas was rarely employed, but the Supreme Court recognized that it was significant nonetheless.
The Portuguese monarchy ended with the death of the King and his heir, followed by a military coup against the subsequent heir just two and a half years later.
Violence is not the only way to remove a monarch from their position.
A perfectly legal and non-violent constitutional amendment could further limit the powers of an ineffective monarch.
In Italy, a peaceful institutional referendum was held in1946 to bring an end to the monarchy.

It is not a sufficient reason to abolish a system of government simply because an official is not elected. For that, it is necessary to demonstrate that an elected official makes a better head of state than a non-elected official.
When the role is ceremonial, it would be a waste of resources to make monarchs votable.
It is difficult to change leadership in a monarchy.
Monarchies do not allow the best leaders to rise to the top.
Monarchs can be forced out of their position if they lose the support of the public.
The monarchs are the leadership only on paper, the actual leadership (the democratically elected prime minister and leading parties) is not difficult to replace.
A power other than a political, temporary majority maintains a division of powers in a monarchy. This is an important check on politicians.
Most monarchs are the sovereign source of executive power but legally devolve it to Parliament. This provides a check on the executive who acts in their name.
A monarchy can serve as a counterbalance to popular opinion. Elected officials by nature are driven by polls. A monarch is insulated from that influence to some degree.
If the monarch's role is politically important, the hereditary nature of their allocation is all the more worrying and undemocratic.
The belief that monarchies act as checks on politicians is a dangerous one. Most monarchies' powers are purely symbolic, meaning governments face no constitutional backstop.

Most European constitutions give the Monarch some specific powers, such as veto powers, signing of laws, retaining the right to rule by decree in the event of democratic indecision, etc. However, true democracies have the ability to decentralize the power of monarch and provide a system of check and balances to their power.
The judiciary can also act to limit a monarch's powers.
Monarchies limit freedom of expression and speech by making criticism of the Crown or members of the royal family a punishable offence.

In Netherlands, intentionally insulting the monarch is punishable by up to five years' imprisonment or a fine, while the same offense against the monarch's spouse, the heir apparent, the heir apparent's spouse or the regent carries up to four years behind bars.
A Dutch activist faced trial in 2015 after being accused of defaming the royals.
One application of these laws in decades just highlights how they are actually very rarely enforced.
Charges were dropped, therefore this is an obsolete argument.

In Monaco, publicly offending the Prince is punishable with imprisonment from six months to five years and a fine according to Article 26(4) of the Criminal Code. If not committed publicly, the act is punished with imprisonment from six months to three years and a fine. Similar laws exist for offending the family of the Prince.

In Belgium, insult towards the King has a punishment of imprisonment from six months to three years and a fine, and insult towards other members of the royal family has a punishment of imprisonment from three months to two years and a fine. In addition, those convicted may be stripped of certain political rights according to the Belgian Criminal Code.
These laws have never been enforced.  The king and his family are routinely attacked by the press, by politicians and by citizens. No one was ever arrested.

In Denmark, the monarch is protected by the usual libel paragraph (Article 267 of the penal code which allows for up to four months of imprisonment), but Article 115 allows for doubling of the usual punishment when a royal is target of the libel.

In Spain, slander or defamation directed against the King or a member of the royal family is a criminal offence under Article 490(3). The penalty is imprisonment from six months to two years if the offence is serious and if not, the penalty is a fine and imprisonment of six to 12 months.
In Spain this can only be enacted if the insult is proven to be untrue, much like any defamation charge.
The fact that it is a criminal charge rather than a civil charge makes it different to most defamation charges.

In Sweden, the punishment of defamation or insult committed against the King or other member of the Royal Family is imprisonment for up to four years, or up to six years in the case of gross defamation (Ch. 18, Sec. 2 of the Criminal Code).
These laws are barely used in today's time.
In 2007 in the Netherlands, a man was sentenced to one week's imprisonment and fined €400 for, amongst other things, lèse-majesté when he insulted Queen Beatrix.
The Spanish satirical magazine El Jueves was fined after publishing an issue with a caricature of the Crown Prince Felipe and his wife engaging in sexual intercourse on the cover in 2007.
Laws prohibiting insult to the head of state aren’t limited to just monarchies and are also present in many republics.
Offending the honor or prestige of the President of Italy is a criminal offence under Article 278 of the Italian Criminal Code. The penalty is imprisonment from one to five years.

Defamation of the German President publicly or through the media is a criminal offence under Article 90 of the German Criminal Code. It carries a potential sentence of three months to five years in prison.
Publicly insulting the President of Poland is a criminal offence under Article 135(2) of the Polish Criminal Code. The penalty is imprisonment for up to three years.
Insult or defamation against the President of Portugal is a criminal offense under Article 328 of the Portuguese Criminal Code. It carries a punishment of three months in prison or a fine.
As of 2015, criticizing the Crown or royals is no longer considered a criminal offense in Norway.
Monarchies are centralistic and territorial, thus work against efforts to distribute power better, within borders and outside.
Monarchies tend to favour centralized systems. Historically, power was concentrated in the monarch and, in modern times, power is exercised by a central government with the support of the monarchy.
The House of Bourbon, the linage of present day Spanish monarchy and previously France, historically imposed a rule that was centralized and uniforming.

In Catalonia, where tensions between central nationalism and peripheral nationalism have escalated, with some citizens demanding independence for the region, the king Felipe VI's message after the 9-O referendum, was seen as a violation from his ceremonial and non-partisan role and a tacit legitimization of the central government.
More distributed and less centralised power is not inherently or necessarily better, whether in a democracy or a monarchy.

From the Middle Age, fragmented Europe benefited from decentralization and jurisdictional competition while the large monarchies in Asia were stagnant. More specifically, governments were forced to adopt better policies because labor and capital had significant ability to cross borders in search of less oppression.
There is a lack of transparency in monarchies.
Royal families are granted protection from public scrutiny.

Spanish journalists have claimed that there is freedom of speech except when it comes to the monarchy: many forms of censorship and self-censorship have made royals a taboo for many years (Tremlett, p. 90).
The British royal family is exempt from the Freedom of Information Acts.
Senior politicians of the UK are sworn to secrecy on their communication with the royals when they take the The Privy Council Oath.
Members of royal families have their every move closely followed by the world's media, which places them under immense scrutiny.
Prince William and Kate have been criticized for doing "ordinary things" like bending down and talking to kids.
In 1992, private telephone conversations between Diana, Princess of Wales, and a close friend, James Gilbey, were recorded and their existence was revealed by The Sun newspaper in an article.

Kate Middleton, the Duchess of Cambridge, was photographed topless while on a private holiday. The pictures, an infringement on Middleton's privacy, appeared in a number of publications all over the world.
Kensington Palace issued a statement about the media intrusion and harassment experienced by Prince Harry's girlfriend after the news of their relationship broke out.
Spain's transparency law does not exempt the royal family.
However, unlike politicians, the assets of the Spanish Royal family have not been disclosed and are a “state secret”.
A study comparing eight West European monarchies with two republics found that republics "offer greater budgetary openness" (Matthijs, p. 263).

Budget oversight is also strict in republics and only the UK and Denmark offer a similar level of oversight, while in the rest of monarchies there is no oversight at all or it is limited (Matthijs p. 264).
The British monarchy has published annual financial statements since 2001.

Transparency International's corruption perceptions index puts 6 constitutional monarchies inside the top 10 countries for their absence of corruption: Denmark, New Zealand, Sweden, Norway, the Netherlands and Canada are all among the very best.

There is a correlation that may be explained by historical reasons: countries in northern Europe are generally perceived as less corrupt than countries in southern Europe, regardless of government form.

Northern countries that are not monarchies like Finland, Switzerland or Germany are perceived as less corrupt while southern and eastern countries like Italy, Greece or Bulgaria are perceived as more corrupt.
Even if there is a slight correlation between monarchies and corruption, that is not a definitive reason to argue democratic monarchies tend to be less corrupted than Republics.
Monarchy helps to sustain the democratic process by mixing an apolitical power with democracy.
The monarch is a politically neutral figure who appeals to everyone and isn’t publicly partisan to any particular view.
Monarchy makes it possible for people who disagree radically about how the nation should be governed to share an object of affection by which the nation as a whole is symbolised.
Many people who disagree radically about how the nation should be governed may disagree with the existence of the monarchy.

It's better to receive an award, medal etc from a monarch who has represented the country for decades rather than a career politician who represents their party; monarchs in contrast are non-partisan, reducing the alienation caused by the polarised nature of party-politics.
A monarch is not tied to any political party or interest group and therefore does not owe their position to a body of voters or the support of powerful interests.
An elected head of state requires help in elections and draws funding from donors that comes with strings attached. This makes a president biased in favour of groups that helped them attain office.
Large campaign donations buy political access and favourable consideration in policy development and legislation.
A republic can cease to be the guardian of the rights of all its citizens and become the privileged domain of one or another group of citizens.
Monarchs do not necessarily "appeal to everyone": they stand in direct opposition to all people who believe in a republican or democratic form of government.
Monarchy is a fundamentally conservative notion.
Monarchs are necessarily political: they stand for their continued rule instead of an elected representative of the people ruled by their government.

Although political neutrality of a monarch works in theory, that is not always the reality. Monarchs and members of the royal family often give up their positions of political neutrality and indulge in lobbying.
Former King of Spain Juan Carlos meddled in politics and questioned a government minister about an anti-hunting law before it was approved by parliament.
Members of the British royal family have been known to indulge in politics directly.
Members of the British royal family were notorious Nazi sympathizers; some members even passed national secrets to Germany during World War II.
Queen Elizabeth II was actively involved in determining the appointment of Prime Ministers in 1957 and 1963 when the leadership of the Conservative party became vacant between general elections.
Ministers have been forced to seek permission from Prince Charles to pass at least a dozen government bills from 2005 to 2011.

Prince Charles took a political and personal stance against China because of the country’s dealings with Tibet and his close friendship with Dalai Lama. He boycotted state visits to China in 1999 and 2005, and refused to attend a state dinner hosted by the Queen for the Chinese head of state in 2015.

It is not necessarily a bad thing for there to be a figure who gains political experience over decades, advises every Prime Minister, and yet has no direct political power and is forced to maintain a public stance of absolute neutrality. This can act as a useful long-view counterbalance to politicians who rarely see beyond the next election.

Considering that a monarch will reign during a long period of time, he or she will necessarily put the people's interests first, whereas any other politician will be more likely to be interested in power/personal interests.
Other forms of government can be prone to extremism due to politicians seeking to push their own agenda. For example, throughout Europe there has been a rise in far-right parties.
Republics such Austria, France, Poland or Hungary have seen a rise in far-right extremist parties.
Monarchies such as Belgium, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and Sweden have also experienced a rise in extremism, proving that democratic monarchies are not immune to this trend.

A elected official might be power hungry but his power is dependent on the will of the people through elections, therefore he will have to keep the people's perceived interests in mind. A monarch in a modern democratic European constitutional monarchy is able to just hang back, do an occasional PR-tour and accrue tax-free wealth paid for by taxation of said populace.
Monarchs can have personal interests as well, such as assets and privileges.

A monarch having interests that do not align with the interests of a country's people is more dangerous than a politician with self-serving interests since a politician can be voted out of office but a monarch cannot.

Monarchical systems may reduce the incumbency advantage a head of government might have when his or her position is combined with the position of head of state. Ceremonial tasks may endear one to the public in a way that is unrelated to substantive political positions.

In countries like France, where there is a President as Head of State and a Prime Minister, even if the President acts on ceremonial and representative tasks (as many other heads of government also do in monarchies or republics) his or her political functions have a great repercussion, so they are as partisan as any other elected politician and thus it is unlikely that representative functions mitigate that to a great advantage.
It is not factually true that monarchies can prevent elected tyrants, since the inception of fascism in Europe occurred in Italy with the support of the then king.
Monarchies are inherently political as they are premised upon the political theory of monarchism.
According to the Freedom in the World survey, all European monarchies are “free” and have high political rights and civil liberties ratings.

The question is not whether the political conditions in countries that happen to have figurehead monarchs are free; rather, the question is whether having a monarchy is compatible with the principles of a free, democratic nation. A monarchy is not compatible with democratic principles.
Other European non-monarchies are just as "free" with just as high political rights and civil liberties ratings. The correlation does not necessarily imply that the Monarchy is the reason.
Many non-European monarchies (such as the UAE or Saudi Arabia) aren't free, this means that freedom and political rights don't depend on having a monarchy as a form of government.

As long as monarchs don't hold explicit political power, monarchy is not incompatible with democracy.
Such a monarchy can perform ceremonial and diplomatic functions in parallel to and at the behest of the sitting government without holding any influence over the democratic process.

Public good provision without discrimination is a feature of liberal democracies. Many democratic socialist countries, especially in Europe, which are also monarchies, provide services like free healthcare and free or state-funded higher education to their citizens. Therefore not all monarchies are necessarily fundamentally opposed to democracy.

Having a strong welfare state, which can be understood as socialist policies, is a common denominator in Europe since the XIX century. However, the values that monarchies interfere with, are not related to that, but to the primal aspects of democracy. That is, egalitarianism, equal opportunities to access elected positions and the possibility to choose those who fill those positions.
Many people would argue that capitalism is also fundamentally opposed to democratic principles and yet capitalism exist in democratic societies.
Democratic principles are just a few of many values a citizen or country can hold.
Whether something does exist or not is irrelevant to whether it should exist or not.
Capitalism is fundamentally opposed to democratic principles, so capitalism should not exist in democratic societies.

Even if one thinks that monarchies are wrong, they are so popular and entrenched that getting rid of them would waste political and activist energy that would be much better spent either on other campaigns or on trying to influence existing monarchies to be more supportive of progressive ideas.
By that logic, any activism or campaign that was challenging and difficult to achieve would be better abandoned. That would make social progress and change really unattainable.

Democracy is based on the important value of equality. Monarchy embedded in democracy embodies and creates institutional space therein for the value of tradition, family and cultural identity. Both therefore are necessary for good and balanced government.

The values of "tradition," "family," and "cultural identity," are not essential elements of democracy. Therefore, even if a monarchy did preserve those values, it would still be incompatible with democratic values.
Cultural identity and tradition can be just as easily be vindicated through democracy, such as in the U.S.
All of these values can be preserved without a monarchy.
The monarch is a symbol of national pride and national unity.
Monarchs can unite a nation in the face of wars or invasions, mustering up a unifying allegiance that can inspire and motivate in times of conflict.
King Haakon VII of Norway united the nation in resisting German invasion during World War II, even threatening to abdicate if the Norwegian government threatened to cooperate with the Germans.
In the UK, King George VI is said to have become a symbol of national resistance during World War II, frequently broadcasting speeches to keep up citizens' morale. (p.102)
There is no reason to think that a republic cannot inspire the same feelings of allegiance.

There is no evidence suggesting that a monarch is more able to unite a people towards a common cause than an elected head of state. One would have to compare the performance of monarchs in modern times versus the performance of elected heads of state, or even dictators to be able to argue the point of superior performance of monarchs.

People do not unite in the face of adversity because of a monarch — they unite because they have something good worth defending. The USA is one of, if not the most, militarily successful countries in history and it has never had or required a monarch.

Such inspiration defers from the actual practical and logical allegiances; it offers a veil to cover what one ought to be and would be fighting for. For example, in an invasion, one defends the country, the people, the things they own and care about. Placing royalty before these things skews good survival-based motivations and instead encourages servility and slavish mentality.

Monarchs are important in multi-ethnic countries because the institution of monarchy unites diverse and often hostile ethnic groups under shared loyalty to the monarch instead of to an ethnic or tribal group.

The monarchy in Belgium is one of the few institutions widely accepted by both the Dutch-speaking Flemings in the north and the French speakers in the southern Wallonia region and the French-speaking enclave of Brussels.
The Belgium royal family, perceived as francophone, always had less support in Flanders and King Philippe (monarch since 2013) has been criticised for not honouring politically neutrality.
However, the former King angered Belgian Flemings when equating the Flemish separatist party to1930s fascism.
Monarchy has no real bearing on how united or divided a country is. Events like royal weddings and jubilees may bring the country together momentarily, but they have no lasting impact.
The existence of the British monarchy hasn’t stopped the push for devolution and even independence in Scotland.
The three European countries with the most active separatist movements are Spain, Belgium and the UK - all monarchies.
Unity is achieved by sharing a belief in a system, a form of government or a nation. This is not limited to monarchy.
There are plenty republics that have loads of symbols of national pride and unity, therefore a monarch is not necessary.
In France, the figure of Marianne is a symbol of pride and unity in the nation.
More extreme examples can be found in North Korea.
Monarchy is an obsolete way to define social identity, in fact none of the real social values within a society are shared between common people and the royals.
The premise for monarchy is not meritocratic and therefore should not be a symbol of national pride or unity as it is not based on the individual contribution to society.

There is no pride in a group of super privileged individuals whose purpose is to maintain some level of popularity. Descendants of a long line of descendants from some historic individual who did justifiably earn the position, but that was a long time ago. Just because someone (in a position they inherited) did a good job doesn't mean they did any better than any other would have done.
A monarch cannot meaningfully signify national pride due to the fact that they have not earned anything they have been born into.

To take pride in the monarch on the basis of their representational function is to take pride away from those who actually worked to make the country; it is to have pride in the actions of others, hiding those actions behind those who parasite upon these working others. This is pretence on part of monarch and the one with pride.
They often dedicate their lives to their nation, and act as diplomats/representatives to the country. They earn it this way, its their duty. This is not an easy job
Monarchs may dedicate their lives to their countries, but they do not earn that through their hard work, as they get into that position by birth.

Whether the monarchy should or should not be a symbol of national pride or unity does not change the fact that in many European countries and for many people, the monarch is indeed a symbol of national pride and unity.
People who are opposed to monarchy do not take pride or feel a sense of national unity due to a monarch.

People can only take pride in what they agree with. If someone does not support the concept of monarchy, then it cannot be a source of pride. Republicans would naturally have pride in the absence of monarchy.

This disuniting factor does not change what the monarch, as a symbol, represents, just as a president with a ceremonial role in a republic would be a symbol of national pride and unity despite not being a source of pride for monarchists.
Monarchy is a stable form of government.
A monarch has a vested interest in a country's success since a country's well-being ensures the monarchy's survival.
Monarchs have a vested interest in the success of their reign and passing off a prosperous kingdom to their heirs.

As regular citizens, elected officials also have a vested interest in the success of their governance, so they can enjoy a prosperous society and so they can pass on a prosperous country to their children.
If the country’s well-being and the continuity of the monarchy are mutually exclusive, monarchs can still choose the option that perpetuates their ruling.

According to the global political stability index of the World Bank, 3 European monarchies are in the top 10 (Liechtenstein, Andorra, Luxembourg), 6 in the top 40 (Norway, Sweden and Netherlands), and all 11 in the top 80.
Liechtenstein, Andorra and Luxembourg are also primarily micro-states, so could be seen as 'oddities'.
Microstates form institutional relationships with larger protectorates to guarantee their political and economic viability; relationships that are dependent on the countries' small size.

These countries' limited human and natural resources have lead to the development of specific economic policies to make up for it, including extremely low taxation and openness to foreign investment.  These are likely to have contributed to the countries' stability to a greater degree, and cannot necessarily be translated to other monarchies in larger countries.
Standard VAT in Andorra (4.5%), Liechtenstein (8%), Switzerland (8%) and Luxembourg (15%) are all lower than in the UK (20%), Spain (21%) and Norway (25%).
Andorra's Corporation Income Tax is 10%, while Liechtenstein's is 12.5% and Switzerland's is 8.5%. All are much lower than Spain's 25% or Belgium's 33.9%.
Corporation Income Tax in Luxembourg (22.05%) is higher than in The Netherlands' (20%).
Monarchies are not inherently stable. For example, monarchies elsewhere in the world are notoriously unstable.

European history shows that monarchies have been oftenoverthrown, and have faced turbulence, which has resulted in quick changes in policy and foreign affairs. Current European monarchies are supported by democracy and those democracies are typically stable, giving the illusion that monarchies are stable.

It isn't a coincidence that these nations are in Europe, which is the second stablest and richest continent in the world (after North America, if we consider it as a continent separated from South and Central America). Even if Syria was a monarchy, it wouldn't be a stable country, due to war. This means stability isn't produced by monarchies, but by economic stability.
The stability of European parliamentary monarchies does not come from the monarchy, but rather the other governmental institutions.

By a similar logic, one can argue that the stability of republics lays in a place other than the republican system itself - as, for instance, the degrees of social peace, social equality, democratic and civic culture of citizens, etc.
Spain, a monarchy, faced 10 months of political instability in 2016 following two inconclusive general elections that failed to produce a government.
In a highly fragmented democratic political system full of minor parties, it is very difficult to reach clear majorities. This is independent of the government form (republic or monarchy).
Modern European monarchies are not forms of government, but merely symbols.
In modern European countries there is no way for monarchs to influence the process of law-making.
Symbols have power too.
Disputes within Royal families have been a major contributor to wars.
Many wars that ravaged Europe since the Middle Ages were due to disputes about monarchical succession.
The reasons for many of the bloodiest wars in Europe were not related mainly to disputes within or between European royal families. One can consider World War I and World War II as two examples.
After the 2010 elections, given the difficulty of generating sufficient alliances, Belgium, a monarchy, broke records by going 8 months without forming a government.
Most European republics have also been stable forms of government.

In the last 20 years, most European countries, monarchies or republics, have been politically stable: in politically stability indexes, except Greece, Croatia, Bulgaria and Spain, none of them have been below 0.
Twenty years is arguably too short a time-span for measuring stability.
The French Fifth Republic has existed since 1958, the Parliamentary Republic of Italy since 1946 and the Federal Republic of Germany since 1949 (with the unification in 1990).
According to a political stability in Europe ranking based on information by the World Bank, Germany is on number 25 France is on 34 and Italy is on 33.
Ever since Italy reconstituted itself as a republic in 1946, it has churned through governments, each one lasting for a little more than a year on average.
Italy's profound social and political fragmentation is historical, as a result of geopolitics, unequal levels of economic development and being repeatedly invaded by foreign powers.
The Kingdom of France existed from 987. The French First Republic was founded in 1792, and they'd reached the Fifth by 1958.

Germany did not become a republic in 1949, it became a republic in 1919. Although it may not have been caused by the lack of a monarchy, the interval between these years could be described as a period of instability.

European republics are not stable given that the continuous change of parties in office is a form of instability. Under a republic, government officials never last long, and countries can be without government for a long time.
Monarchy can bring stability to a country, when it has no government or specially between elections.
The top three politically stable countries in Europe are monarchies: Liechtenstein, Andorra and Luxembourg.
Monarchs are more effective political figures than elected executives.
European monarchs do not fuel anger against a certain part of the population for electoral purpose.
The monarch is a permanent diplomatic figure who is respected and appreciated.
Even former monarchs can play an important diplomatic role: for example, former Spanish King Juan Carlos is regarded as the best ambassador of the country.
This does not mean that all monarchs will be good diplomats.

Since his abdication, former King Juan Carlos I no longer has official duties: he is reported to have been traveling, resting, treating his hip injury, eating out and planning to create his own foundation and has barely been in official acts.

Juan Carlos I was not invited to the event celebrating the 40th Anniversary of the arrival of democracy in Spain. As the protocol dictates that it is the Head of the State who addresses Congress, the emeritus King had no official place.

His image has also deteriorated due to rumours of divorce and paternity claims. A 2017 scandal revealed that many years ago, the secret services paid large sums to an actress not to divulge a romantic affair.
The monarch carries out international public visits thus alleviating the elected Prime Minister or President from these duties and allowing them to run the country more effectively.
The monarch is important for national business and international relations, as foreign spokespeople behave differently with a monarch than with a president.
When dealing with more autocratic regimes, monarchs hold more sway in the minds of autocratic leaders.
The UK has success in working with Gulf States when their royals act as diplomats.
Usually the word of a president is held in higher regard since they actually represent their nation, people and parliament.
Because many modern monarchs are largely symbolic and wield little power, their ability to negotiate treaties or deals with other nations is vastly limited.
Whether a monarch is respected and appreciated is a subjective claim.
Professional diplomats can be better than a monarch.
Ambassadors have achieved a long and high level professional training specifically for that purpose.
French diplomatic service seems to be the best in Europe, winning over British diplomacy.

There is nothing inherent in being a monarch that commands respect. Because monarchs come to power by accident of birth, they might be insane, stupid, incompetent, or have other bad personality traits.
From the moment they are born, monarchs are usually better trained and educated to deal with political affairs than most politicians.
Monarchs are likely to receive an international education, attend the best schools and choose degrees related to their royal duties.

The Spanish King Felipe VI has had an international education, studying in a private school in Canada, then graduating in Law in Madrid and studying an MA in International relationships in the US. He has also received training at each of Spain’s armed services.

Prince William took a two-year training programme in the art of kingship drawn up by the Queen and Prince Charles which included working in different Whitehall departments to get a better idea of how government works, private instruction from constitutional experts, and briefings by privy councilors.
Politicians have also traditionally attended leading educational institutions - 75% of the UK's Prime Ministers attended the country's top universities, Oxford and Cambridge.
A large proportion of politicians in the UK completed the PPE (Politics, Philosophy and Economics) undergraduate degree at Oxford.

Monarchs are not the only well-educated people in a country, and, especially in the case of higher education, it is hard to ensure they were capable or worthy of attending a prestigious university. Being who they are, it is hard, if not impossible, to believe they've been held up to the same performance and evaluation standards as their peers throughout their education.
Politicians do not know since an early age that they will become the heads of their respective states, and are therefore not able to invest their time and resources to educate and prepare themselves.

At 18 years old the Spanish King Felipe VI swore allegiance to the Crown and was formally declared the heir. He has spent 28 years (1986-2014) expecting to be king and preparing himself for his royal role.

The diplomatic and ceremonial aspects of governing, which the monarchy performs, require a keen sense of tradition, history and familiarity with protocol. Nurture matters more than nature with regards to these qualities.

Politicians may not know from birth what position they will occupy, but those successful in reaching positions of power must compete through the ranks over time. This time is spent garnering the knowledge, experience and preparation required to be deemed eligible for a position at the top.
Before being publicly elected, most politicians spend years facing internal processes in which they have to demonstrate negotiating skills and charisma to rise within their parties.

François Mitterrand, the longest-serving French president, was a successful strategist who combined different political influences: a conservative and Catholic upbringing, his time serving under the Vichy Regime, a participation in the Nazi resistance and a successful political career in the Socialist Party.
In the UK, Liberal Democrats and Conservatives go through assessment processes that are ardours and difficult as well as very professionalised and based on competency.

Before being elected (1982), former Spanish President Felipe González became a member of the clandestine socialist party and was elected its Secretary General once. He had a decisive role during the Spanish transition to democracy and became a member of Congress (1977). In contrast, Spanish King Felipe VI had not had a comparable political background before becoming king.

King Felipe VI also has a very distinct role to play in Spanish politics to the Prime Minister, and as such does not need to have the same level of political experience to undertake his job effectively.
It is just as likely that the people would elect a demagogue or an inept individual.
Unlike a monarch, a demagogue or inept can be voted out of office in the next election.
Monarchs spend many years observing the institution from the inside and therefore probably have a much better idea of the machinations of the post than most politicians do theirs.
Belgium's Prince Laurent has a history of unorthodox foreign meetings.
As most monarchs have ceremonial power, their training in many cases involves protocol, foreign languages and an overall view of political affairs but not real political skills.

Someone elected to run the country is likely to have extensive experience in politics and is therefore more qualified to run the country than someone with no previous governmental or direct political experience.
Theresa May, former British prime minister, is the second longest serving home secretary in more than 100 years and has held several positions within Parliament since 1997.
Somebody with a history in public office may be more likely to have old political affiliations and therefore struggle to put the country's interests first.

The last Italian President of the Republic, Giorgio Napolitano, was referred to as 'Re Giorgio' (i.e. King Giorgio) due to his long history of involvement in Italian politics and subsequent dominance in the sphere.
Giorgio Napolitano was a leading figure in the Communist party forover 40 years, up until its dissolution.
Napolitano was accused of plotting to bring down Berlusconi's centre-right government by holding meetings with Monti, the new appointment, before Berlusconi had been called to step down.

Napolitano has overseen parties from both the left and right wings, as well as a cross-party coalition and received cross-party support for his election as President. This indicates that he could rule without party biases. He is regarded as a beacon of stability by many.

Standing for election and running a country are two highly different and disparate things, with no correlation or causation between them. A person skilled at looking popular and winning elections is not the same a person who is a good, effective and competent leader.
The best politicians have had life experiences outside of politics.

Winston Churchill, two-times Prime Minister of the UK and regarded as one of the most influential leaders of the wartime era, was an officer of the British Army, an artist, a historian and a talented writer, awarded with the Nobel Prize in Literature.

German leader Angela Merkel was a former scientific researcher and has a doctorate in physical chemistry before she became a politician. She has been Chancellor of Germany since 2005. She is regarded as a great politician due to her long tenure.

There is no meritocratic evaluation between someone born into a royal family who receives the best training and any other person who might receive the same. Therefore any superiority of a monarch due to training is presumed and cannot be tested empirically as in an election or other evaluation.

It is impossible to conceive of an institution outside of the monarchy able to combine to the same measure grandeur and the delicate mix of neutrality and societal engagement necessary for the optimal performance of the ceremonial duties of the state.

The Crown, composed of various members, permits that the representation of the State is simultaneously present in different places. The King might be dealing with major items of the Governments' agenda while the Queen, Princes and Princesses are supporting cultural, diplomatic or social initiatives together with charity events, etc. The duties of the head of State can be organically shared multiplying the country's presence.
Monarchs are not chosen by their biological or genetic characteristics that make them better at politics, but just by accident of birth.

There is nothing inherent in monarchy that makes monarchs more effective. Because monarchs are born into the position and not put there by merit, an insane, stupid, or incompetent monarch could come to power.
Politicians are not put there by merit, but by popularity. Popularity does not equate to competence or qualification.
Additionally, due to the extreme inbreeding of some royal houses, leading to very small gene pools, genetic diseases have been problematic for monarchs.

Modern royal houses have mainly married commoners in recent years. The Duke of Windsor famously married a commoner, the Duke of Cambridge has married a commoner,  the Prince of Wales married a commoner (two of them), and Prince Harry married a commoner.

The fact that in recent years most royal families marry commoners, does not detract from the fact that for centuries, the level of inbreeding between royals has been considerably high, even making royals more prone to genetic diseases.
Elected politicians are chosen by characteristics that make them better at getting elected, not by characteristics that make them better at governing.
Every existing royal dynasty was, necessarily, founded by someone so exceptionally good at politics that they founded a royal dynasty that survived to the present day.

Most of the suggested benefits of having unelected lifelong party-neutral political actors (the royals) could, in principle, be fulfilled through appointed positions based on merit rather than biological heritage, as it already happens in some political or judicial positions.

Judges in the UK (and European democracies with analogous principles of Judicial Independence), are appointed based on merit (some with life long tenure) and can exert a non-partisan influence on the application of law in the country which takes into account principle, rather than short-term political gain.

Crossbench life-peers in the UK House of Lords are an example of life-long non-partisan political actors chosen based on merit, who influence legislation and can take into account the long term interests of the country.

Monarchs undertake their roles out of duty or obligation, rather than a real desire or vocation to support their nation, meaning they may be less likely to dedicate as much time to their responsibilities.
Prince Harry of the UK admitted that younger monarchs are reluctant to take to the throne but will do so out of duty.
Heads of state spend huge amounts of time on functions and state visits.
The monarch in a constitutional monarchy is not required to 'run the country'.
An understanding of the country's constitution and ceremonial practices are more important than applied political experience.

Modern-day European monarchies do not, and should not have extensive power. The governmental institutions of each country, which are accountable to citizens, notably through elections, wield political power.
Monarchies are the best political systems in order to guarantee freedom and democracy.
So-called "Presidents for Life" achieve more easily power in countries without Monarchy.
Most historic examples of "Presidents for Life" are not found in contemporary Europe and are definitely not found in actual democratic systems.
Monarchs deflect a lot of public attention allowing the executive space to get on with the functions of state.
Monarchy is a symbol of democracy and freedom for some countries.
The Dutch monarchy is associated with freedom from foreign rule: first from that of the French under Napoleon in the early 19th Century and later from Nazi Germany in 1945.
In the 70s, the Spanish King Juan Carlos I facilitated the transition from a dictatorship to democracy.
While Spaniards can appreciate what King Juan Carlos did for the country, this does not transform every citizen into a convinced monarchist.
The monarch has the power to solve political crises and mediate between parties.
In a national crisis, when the people and the Parliament are in serious disagreement, the monarch of the UK can personally exercise their reserve powers without the advice and consent of ministers.

This would cause a constitutional crisis, because the powers given to parliament preserve democracy.  Should the sovereign overrule the government, then they would become a dictator.  Therefore the powers can never actually be exercised, (whilst maintaining a democracy).

A reigning European monarch is the ultimate proof of democracy, for the people are free to instruct parliament to abolish monarchy, upon which parliament would act, which is the ultimate expression of democracy.

The monarchy of Liechtenstein has leveraged its financial power (as owners of the principality's biggest bank and asset management fund), to consolidate their political power and sway public referendums.
In 2003, Prince Hans Adam threatened to move to Austria, along with his financial enterprise, if he was not awarded greater constitutional powers. His demands were duly met.
Monarchies inhibit royals themselves from living freely.
Most monarchs cannot express political opinions or participate in elections.
The King of Spain can legally vote, however, as he is the Head of State and should be neutral and be above partisan politics, he does not vote.

Monarchy often hurts rights to personal expression of the monarch or the monarch's children (universal declaration of human rights article 19) whereas e.g. in the Netherlands the monarch is not allowed to just say anything but has to discuss any public talk with a minister.
The sovereign of the UK cannot vote, as according to the British Parliament's website, it is deemed unconstitutional for the monarch to vote.

One of the monarch's roles in a constitutional monarchy is to be a non-partisan political figure that can act as a back-stop to constitutional issues. As such, expressing a political view would compromise their intended role.
This role is true of all non-partisan Heads of State, not just monarchs.
Most royals cannot marry freely.

To 'maintain the status of the royal house', the 1772 Royal Marriages Act decreed that all members of the UK royal family must seek permission from the sovereign to marry their person of choice. The sovereign has the right to object.
Succession to the Crown Act 2013 replaced the Royal Marriages Act 1772, according to which only the first six in line to the British throne need the Queen's consent to marry.
There is no legal barrier that keeps a British royal from marrying someone of a different religion or faith.

The Bill of Rights 1689 and the Act of Settlement 1701 that restricted succession to the British throne to only Protestant descendants of Princess Sophia were amended in 2013. Those who marry Roman Catholics are no longer disqualified from the line of succession.
In Denmark, the monarch must have the Parliament’s permission to marry.
In Sweden, the heir needs the Government’s consent to marry, otherwise, they lose succession rights for themselves and their descendants.
It took seven years for Princess Victoria of Sweden to get her father and the Government's consent to be able to marry a commoner, Daniel Westling, her personal trainer.

Spanish royals could not marry non-royals due to the Pragmática Sanción of 1776, yet the Constitution now establishes that they do not need the permission of the King or the Parliament to marry and remain in the succession line.

However, the Constitution does establish that there must not be a prohibition by both the King and the Parliament on the potential marriage. If both opposed, according to the law, the marriage could not be celebrated.
In order to be in line of succession, royals in some countries need to profess a specific faith.
In Denmark, the monarch has to be a member of the Lutheran Evangelical church.
A member of the British royal family must be in communion with the Church of England and does not have the freedom to be of another faith.

Laws in Sweden still demand that royals profess “pure evangelical faith” (Church of Sweden) and that any member of the Royal Family who does not will be excluded from the succession (Nergelius, p. 43).

Heads of State can sometimes see their personal lives constrained by security issues or other circumstances, yet that is a small tradeoff if they are able to guarantee freedom for their people and a stable government.
Royal Heads of State have stronger and arbitrary (e.g. no freedom of religion or to marry freely) limitations imposed into their lives compared with non-royal Heads of State.
A monarch can Abdicate

Simply stating that a monarch can abdicate, assumes that any given individual, in any given situation, can be defined as always having a choice. Royal families are generally long and glorious lines of succession through a family tree, and the whole concept is steeped in tradition and pride. It is unlikely that an environment like that lends itself lightly to "opting out", or abdicating, as it were.
